QVC, the No. 1 shopping-TV station, began putting up ads for its Black Friday specials more than six weeks in advance. In addition, the Philadelphia-based network is moving its Thanksgiving Day programming, usually a day of airing cooking demonstrations, to the day after in order for shoppers to have its pre-Black Friday specials through the day. QVC could be more flexible because its audience, existing customers, doesn't rely on a heavy period to boost sales.

Not all bananas are the same. Different types of bananas contain varying amounts of the sugars fructose and glucose.
One study in 30 healthy adults compared the effects of eating various types of bananas on blood glucose levels. The study participants ate apples or bananas and measured their fasted blood glucose one hour into the experiment. The results revealed that the blood glucose levels rose more in those who ate the granny smith variety when compared to the other types. When comparing bananas with a blood glucose response, the pineapples and apple caused lower blood glucose concentrations than bananas.

As a teenager, Lynn Blake walked home with her dad as he received his paycheck and then promptly took it from him.
"He washed dishes at radiator repair shop and he had a bad reputation for pulling people in there for a beer only to be charged for repairs," she said. "I just took it. I didn't know better."
She found out better when she woke up to reality. It was her first childhood lesson in effective salesmanship.

Steve Trevor (Chris Pine) seemingly met his end, but Patty Jenkins confirms there's room to explore his immortality in a Wonder Woman 2 that focuses on Diana (Gal Gadot) finding her place in the world.
The director, while speaking with Collider, confirmed that Wonder Woman 2 will see Diana exploring Manhattan, partying with pals Steve and Etta (Ewen Bremner) and developing her Amazon skillset.
“We haven’t heard from her for long enough that we need to come in and show what she’s doing and where her world is," Jenkins explained. "The world that she needs to create for herself in America, what her mentors are, her weird girlfriends, her lovely and wonderful boyfriend, the way that she is trying to grow herself in the world that is very different from [than what she knows]."

Those governments will have relatively few coalition partners to turn to for a quick vote on tough measures, Legislators don't have to look for support among opponents (to the right or left) and must try to begin legislating immediately. The result is fewer, faster decisions and less opportunity for compromise between left-leaning and right-leaning legislators. Something is better than nothing, but not much better is what the votes are saying.

On her wedding ring finger, Julie Corbisiero of Columbus flashed a ticket she said represented the feeling of everything getting better in her life.
The ticket was for the Powerball lottery and, she said, printed the numbers 15, 33, 17, 31 and the Powerball of 46, after penciling in her own number 17 as her lucky charm.
The numbers matched those from Monday night’s Powerball jackpot drawing, worth an estimated $162 million but still beckoning the verdict of only one winner.
Corbisiero, 46, said her hand started to shake as she held the slip of paper Monday night – a change from her usual cool, cash-in-hand approach.
On her advice, her daughter also picked numbers from dreams she had had a year ago, she said.

. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men are simply genetically programmed to experience hair loss. This form of hair loss is usually caused by a hormone called dihydrotestosterone or DHT.
DHT interferes with the process by which the scalp makes new cells to replace older ones. It has been referred to the male (Andro-Genic) hair grower hair loss.
Who gets male hair loss?
The usual age for male hair loss to begin is between 30 and 40. While genetics come into play here too, it is also possible to have normal levels of dihydrotestosterone and have hair loss.
This form of hair loss is usually caused by male pattern baldness, the most common type of hair loss. This condition is certainly more likely to affect men with strong family histories. Arthur Frank, MD, claims any man can develop hair loss,

giving scientists more tools to study how climate change could affect marine life.
Kakazei and his colleagues provide a first step. In a paper published in Global Biogeochemical Cycles, the team reports the work of 33 marine phytoplankton species observed in samples collected from the Delaware coast. With their algal diversity and genetic differences, the 20 species featured in the study help scientists observe ocean productivity. The team used genomic sequencing to better understand the relationship between blue green algae and environmental factors, such as population density, light intensity, temperature, acidity, wave action and nutrients.

At least 110 boats from around the Midwest, including Michigan and Ohio, traveled to Troy to display their ships of the past.
Since its relocation from Pontiac three years ago, the Black River Festival has attracted major exhibitors and expansive crowds.

The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting technical regulations with design solutions after the fact, and is also more trustworthy than competing system run by the World Trade Organisation.
Until the end of the 1990s, however, the Commission approved car emissions before they are actually produced, ensuring in theory that only cars that meet EU standards can be sold in Europe. However, the system is now under strain, as bilateral treaties between member states and Asia dim its importance.
"The Commission wants to be relegated to a rubber stamp, it is less important for the Commission to do this job," Lukas Mach, an expert at the European Environment Bureau (EEB), told this newspaper in reaction to a presentation at a Commission session on 15 May.

larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful of clients at a time. To meet higher demand from clients, smaller companies may rent server resources from larger vendors. As a result, reseller hosting companies rent server space from larger providers and resell that space to smaller companies. Instead of renting physical space on the provider's server, you will be essentially reselling the provider's services to potential clients. Reseller hosting has grown in popularity over the years in part because of the time, technology and resources required to operate a web-hosting business. With web hosting services, the city in which your clients are located can affect the time it takes to rent server resources. If the company is based in the Midwest, for example, it may take two or three hours for a change to take effect if clients are using servers that are sold in another city. Successful resellers can charge more for their services and have the money

The iSi Perfect Pour, a.k.a. The iSi PP 2, is a line of mini-N2 cartridges for cocktails, coffee, and other delicious beverages. What does N2 mean? To understand that, it’s important to first understand what nitro means. At the most simplest terms N2 is room temperature water and nitro is nitrogen. professionals identify which options, or the methods behind those options, are most effective at achieving a certain end objective – much like a flowchart, information flow diagram, or a mapping of logical steps.
Decision trees are heavily based on a cost/benefit analysis, and identify multiple elements on which someone’s decision will be based. Trees can be put together by one person, a team or even the public via a survey questionnaire.
Decision trees have a distinct look to them – a set of branches forming a tree-like shape that guides you to an appropriate decision or outcome – but other flow charts have slightly different usage and looks.
Decision trees are used in an array of fields, including project management, business analysis, customer relationship management and others. So how can the application of these decision trees be improved?
Clarity rather than accuracy is a goal we should strive for while diagnosing problems with decision tree

Were it not for his contributions to experimental music and art, he mightn’t even have made an impression in the afterlife either. Instead Maloney lived—and died—as Pat Maloney, an anonymous understated life. In sickness he remained tolerably stoic. In health he was not particularly cheerful. Now he’s buried beneath a copy of Einstein’s Collected Works. With a few detours and a sense of distance, his path was undeniably short despite being a grand one: he played in bands, he worked on a computer, he collaborated with theatre professionals and helped bring their art into being. The study, published this week in the open journal PLOS ONE, compared 75 grandmothers who spent an evening in Brazil relaxing with their grandchildren with 75 grandmothers in the United States. Participants were 63 years old on average and classified their health, both physical and mental, as "excellent."
Both groups were asked to identify their best "fuse moment." Fuse, the authors explain, is the amount of time it takes a person to go from being upset to angry. This measurement is considered to be an indicator of self-control. Participants also filled out questionnaires and were given a series of means to identify their stress levels. The grandmothers in Brazil spent time significantly less than their U.S. counterparts - about 30 minutes less (about 11 fuses).

Historically Hive users have been frustrated that, as the job gets more complex, the job's performance degrades. Without parallelizing this performance begins to degrade exponentially with each task added to the query. Stinger changes this by allowing Hive jobs to exist in a world of separated instances of parallel Hive, opting in at any time, as they do now micromanage resource pooling.
The changes make it possible to have managed instances of Hadoop that get config changes to specify resource base configurations, and accepting those configurations in these worlds of parallel Hive. This new scheme allows admins or the developers of the configured machine to keep Hive from being the bottleneck that causes the query to slow.

The celebration of the Nativity of Jesus properly belongs to the Faith and worship of the Christian Church….
Before the middle of the fifth century, the Faith and worship of the Christian Church did not include the celebration of the Birth of Jesus. Whatever stories and legends collectionary Christian writers might originate would ultimately take second place in the popular and wider culture overall to events such as the Nativity and Baptism of Jesus, and Would have little importance. * Bogus e-mails that appear to come from tax software providers requesting financial institutions to update taxpayer information are a recurrent threat.

Brain scans reveal how dad's Zika virus affected baby's generation
ATLANTA, Feb 7 (Reuters) - Four months after risking his life on the front lines in Jacmel, Haiti, during the 2010 earthquake, Gonzalo Macias learned his infant son might have something in common with him: Zika virus.
"It was kind of an instant shock," the Houston, Texas, resident said. "I never even thought about the possibility of him having some symptoms. He was a little young, of course, but I was confident in her (the doctor's) experience and knowledge, and he was well and happy."
When the virus is passed from mother to fetus, it typically leads to microcephaly, in which a baby's head is smaller than expected and brain development is stunted. It is difficult to develop conclusive evidence

Get Insurance before You Land
If you or anyone in your party has a problem with driving, see if your home or auto policy will pay for liability if there's an accident That only works if your agent has been told about your trip, unless there's an auto rental exclusion to the policy. You'd be guinea pig if you had a wreck and the insurance company denied coverage. Check with your agent and find out, because this limitation can be a counter-intuitive surprise. In either case, reconsider signing your name until you've checked. In our lean years, we've gone without rental car insurance to avoid outrageously expensive insurance from the rental companies. On the other hand, see if your homeowner's policy provides supplementary liability with the rental car, and you can drive with less stress.

my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different geometric patterns into the light transmuting blue surface. My mother noticed a fragment of the modernist pattern I had created and printed it in black on a tablecloth.
Decades later, when shopping in Edinburgh one day, I stopped in a George Street bookstore where I was introduced to the iconic classic Bauhaus 2 software, by Werner Jekelius and Martin Kluger. I started university the following year at Glasgow School of Art and started to incorporate simple form with colour to my designs – the element of Bauhaus resonated.

General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a comprehensive plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. As the EU’s data privacy watchdog – the Office of the Information Commissioner – shares data-related best practices with regulators worldwide, the legislation ultimately could impact consumers and businesses around the world. It could also impact the legal landscape of the United States.
In the United States, both public and private-sector organizations – including small to medium-sized businesses – are under increasing pressure to strengthen data protection, as cybercriminals are getting craftier by increasing their attacks.
Organizations should understand and execute on key GDPR provisions to minimize risks. Those provisions include:
● Consent: Why is it important? This relates to how people’s personal data is used. Consent requires affirm

What sets Femara apart from Arimidex is that it is designed to have less toxicity and thus less side effects than Arimidex. This makes it a great option for what is called an adjuvant therapy, wherein one is using an anti-estrogen drug after treatment is complete. Why is this great? In a report, the Government Accountability Office found that in the DoD just three out of 10 major procurement decisions met criteria for affordability. That means that for every $10 spent on military equipment and infrastructure, just $3 was good value.
GAO defined “good value” as an acquisition process that delivers what you want, when you want it at a cost and schedule that the key stakeholders agreed to. In other words, it’s a test of the military’s capacity to meet their responsibility to protect America’s interests with the resources the taxpayer gives them. The line is a self-contained quote from Pulp Fiction that is famous for its nebulous insinuation, profound foreshadowing, and penultimate use as the film’s title. But one party is missing on the back room talky, and that’s Jules. Since he doesn’t seem to be present when Honey Bunny says Mia Wallace took the gun out of her purse, it’s understandable that the phrase could have gone in many directions. But as we discuss in this essay, the phrase could have also been included in order to point to a coming cryptic, parallel development held between Vincent and Mia once “Vincent Vega” — the film’s most famous insertion of back-room-talk — would have isolated these encounters with Honey Bunny and Jules.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 700 potential carcinogenic agents and concluded that processed meat causes colorectal cancer. Their latest announcement does not mean that people should not eat meat, but rather that processed meat should be eaten in moderation.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a fight between Republican lawmakers and President Barack Obama.
Americans will either see their nation lay off an economically disastrous road or do the right thing and end the decade-long war in Afghanistan.”
Lew, speaking a day after the election handed Democrats the Senate, said it is part of the job of the next Congress to ensure the nation avoids recession because the consequences of doing otherwise are too high.
Time is running out for Congress to stretch a government funding extension by Dec. 15. Congress could also fail to raise the federal borrowing limit, the so-called debt ceiling.
The Republican-led House of Representatives clashed with Obama over the borrowing limit during budget showdowns that have slashed the federal budget over the past several years and taken the U.S. government to the brink of default.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $10 million over nine hours on Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving that traces its roots to department stores.
QVC, the No. 1 shopping-TV station, began putting up ads for its Black Friday specials more than six weeks in advance. In addition, the Philadelphia-based network is moving its Thanksgiving Day programming, usually a day of airing cooking demonstrations, to the day after in order for shoppers to have its pre-Black Friday specials through the day. QVC could be more flexible because its audience, existing customers, doesn't rely on a heavy period to boost sales.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to Sylwester Linowski, head of emerging markets investment at Allianz Global Investors. WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to bridge pervasive, bitterly polarized partisan disputes that have roots as wide ranging as maintaining U.S. dominance in national security affairs to limiting the power of the federal purse.
Republicans have dominated the agenda so far in Obama’s term and his conciliatory speech might be interpreted by some as evidence that he had capitulated to GOP leaders and moderate Democrats rather than lead his party’s liberal base.
One Democratic senator, Walter Shelby of South Carolina, an opponent of the health care overhaul Obama won with party-line support, called the speech an indication that the president wants to go to the right. Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Jackie Kopecek on May 19, 2002. She died on July 23, 2009.

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget balance less one-off, temporary and other cyclical movements of actual revenue. Stability is used as normality, where actual growth of revenue around a trend is assumed countercyclical. Deviations from stability are based on a measure of over- or undershooting, giving more weight to deviations nearer cyclical troughs or peaks.
In the previous year, 2014, General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel was -1.73 % . General General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel averaged 0.83 % from 1998 until 2015, reaching an all time high of 6.14 % in 2010 and a record low of -4.47 % in 2013.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would have been an obvious candidate as recently as 20 or 30 years ago but now that we are ranked 20th for maternal mortality, the US has claimed the dubious crown.
Over there the maternal mortality rate is on the rise and is now the highest it has been amongst industrialised nations since the early 1900's. How this can happen in a country where life expectancy is 75 years women’s death in childbirth is now more common than among women who have breast cancer. That is astounding.

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue rose 6% in the fiscal first quarter to $8.5 billion and net income rose 23% to $1.11 billion, or $1.57 a share, the Beaverton, Oregon-based company said late on Thursday.
Analysts expected revenue of $8.46 billion and earnings of $1.46 a share.
Nike sales in North America jumped 5%, while its international business rose 4%.
Nike said footwear revenues rose 6%, while apparel jumped 11%.
Full-year forecasts are now for revenue of $30 billion and to earn $1.97 a share.
For the current year, Nike CFO Eric Sprunk said the company was also "pleased with slight improvement in margin" as inventory declined, "which allowed for less promotions and stronger sales."

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green foliage supporting small trusses of flowers.
D. personata makes an attractive low growing shrub with pink flowers and sparsely pubescent foliage. A yellowish-white flowered form, White House, has the unusual feature that the foliage is green in summer and turning bronze in winter.
Since the shade-tolerant specimens began to replace massed Agapanthus in showy gardens in South Africa 30 years ago the genus has almost completely disappeared from fashion in the United States as well as being neglected in Europe. The recent boom in interest planting including many heat- and drought-tolerant Gardenias and Clivias in American landscapes is making it fashionable to use less familiar exotics as alternatives to traditional, but thirsty, flourishers in shade.

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, followed by a month in Eastern Europe. After meeting up with friends in Salzburg, Austria, we headed east, toward Budapest.
A dark night. I sat in the back of a shaky VW we rented days before, with five of my friends. It was black outside. Other than the blood red headlights of the VW we traveled in, it was pitch black everywhere. The car we rented was a front passenger vehicle with fewer safety features than a taxi. Furthermore, the steering was loose. On more than one occasion the driver lost control.
Yet, I fell asleep and dreamed of the sunlight and sand in Germany and Europe.
I woke up abruptly, awestruck. I glanced out the window. The driver had stopped on shoulder of the road. We had made a sudden, unprompted and unexpected stop after being in the pitch black of an overcast night

The shooting at about 11:30 p.m. in the eastbound freeway involved three or four vehicles near Alondra Boulevard, said California Highway Patrol Officer A. Rivera.
The victim, who was in a black Acura, was pronounced dead at a hospital. Two other people in that vehicle were being treated at a hospital, Rivera said. No arrests have been reported.
The precise motive remained under investigation. The exact number of the shooting victims also remained unclear. CHP Officer Luis Alvarez said more victims may be sought as the investigation continues.

There are lots of toddler activities your librarian can share with you. What’s more, they come from all around the world. My daughter recently returned from a road trip around Mexico and various books to visit. Librarians are a pretty cosmopolitan bunch, so one can discover lots of wacky activities and games from all kinds of places.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come from local communities, rather than being imposed on them by higher authorities, and from a shift in capital flows, says Naoko Ogikubo, Advisor to the UN Environmental Programme (UNEP) in Geneva.
IPS: What is the main message that you want to convey to the government?
Ogikubo: The message is that the policies for restructuring the economy to achieve environmental sustainability must start at the local level. In many countries worldwide, solutions lie in effective governance, fair taxation, enlightened fiscal policy and a more responsible and ethical business and finance sector. Such measures require that governments determine and implement policies that reflect the interests of the whole spectrum of society and that reflect local realities. In other words, it means raising awareness on SDGs [sustainable development goals].

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr’s speech on climate action at Massey College in Toronto on Wednesday also launched a broadside against carbon pricing schemes that are opposed by many conservative provincial leaders, such as Ontario Premier Doug Ford.
Federal leaders face growing pressure to enact more ambitious or efficient measures to reduce Canada’s GHG emissions as countries gather for the UN Climate Change Conference beginning today in Madrid.
Carr dismissed the idea that measures to cut emissions can be counterproductive.
“We have to face that our economy depends on fossil fuels and historically, that has been the dominant value in the energy community,” Carr told business and civic leaders at Massey College. “That’s about sustainable asset management because fossil fuels are finite,” he said, citing Spain’s efforts while offering no details on Ottawa’s forthcoming climate action plan, which will be released next year.

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been charged with vague, almost baffling allegations of espionage, including writing articles about Iran’s nuclear programme as a US agent, lasted less than 30 minutes. A court session on Sunday night lasted for a total of five minutes, and then on Monday for an hour or so.
The case against Rezaian began to reveal its contradictions, that the charges of espionage were earlier described as investigations in the newspaper regarding Iran and its hosting of the Syrian civil war, talks with the western powers on sanctions, or indeed its nuclear programme. The same information was given to the newspapers extensively and widely without any suggestion of being an agent for the US government.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered that emergency drought preparations be maintained in their three northernmost counties: Modoc, Trinity and Mendocino.
Also Friday, Brown declared an end to a statewide state of emergency that he first issued five years ago due to poor snowfall.
More than 100 California counties were still under some form of drought declaration as of Thursday, according to an online drought tracker compiled by the U.S. Drought Monitor.

Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference. Gutmann, a computer science professor at the University of Auckland in New Zealand, presented a paper at the conference that describes the problems customers are experiencing with Microsoft's content protection technology -- the technology inside the company's setup of Windows Media Player which provides even encrypted audio to users the listening experience they want on their systems. Gutmann said that these security features actually prevent customers from watching high-quality audio and video because the GUI interface and even encrypted portions of content are blocked for users. "It amazes me because the users are like, 'gee, thanks for helping me degrade my video and my audio,'" he added. Worldwide circulation of incomplete versions of Disney's film Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl was quickly detected, suggesting that security experts are unlikely to catch a widespread pirate campaign. Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 21st Asean Summit in November.
Under the rules, journalists from the US, Australia, Canada, the UK, and Asean countries such as Indonesia and Singapore now need to register with in the local media authorities and have to attend faculties as well before being allowed to cover proceedings.

For decades Laos has cracked down on the free press in line with the secretive communist government's policy of strict state control over the media.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by a California-based low-fare carrier.
United revealed its pricing after a filing in federal bankruptcy court indicating no more oversize carry-on bags would be allowed. Club and first-class customers will nevertheless be allowed to fly with one carryon item.
Exactly when check baggage fees will be introduced has been a centering contest. United said it was reducing carry on space "if sufficient space in overhead storage bin is unavailable." But the final surcharge will probably roll out after Madison Avenue shops finish retooling their advertisements for United, analysts said.
Vice president Christopher Bryant--who has pressed United on the slowness of introducing extra fees--said customers at airport counters often didn't know discount fares didn't include the carry on change.

One bill sponsored by University of Montana President Royce Engstrom would create an independent board of directors to administer Montana University System hiring, bidding and procurement contract procedures and statewide campus safety standards in cases in which crimes have been committed.
“The legislation is a comprehensive approach that comes out from the recommendations that the Montana Safeway Task Force came out with in February 2017,” Engstrom said. “There is a commitment that will end this year that states that we’re going to work to find more accurate data, more reliable data with crimes that are committed on our campuses and that might involve sexual violence or student safety or even violence so there can be something that the campus community is better able to rely on to prevent and track and eliminate these types of crimes.”

Consumers with the products should toss them out or return them to the place of purchase for a full refund, the company said. The recall includes only Unilever-branded products.
Listeria is a food-borne bacteria that causes fever, muscle aches and in more serious cases, death.
Symptoms of listeria usually appear within a month after eating a contaminated food, which is mostly commonly in deli meat. The disease causes up to 1,600 illnesses a year in the United States, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story.
ZeeMee is a new crowd-sourcing website that allows students to give their trusted networks of relatives, friends and neighbors — including teachers and volunteers — access to their entire ZeeMee profile that includes academic transcripts, extracurricular activities and other "life stories" that help round out their application to college. It's what co-founder Steven Bocchieri refers to as "accessible word-of-mouth, overrated!"
We spoke with Bocchieri and John Stanton, the other co-founder, who are garnering some high-profile seed funding from investors including Axel Springer and Steve Case. The idea is that you want to know more about the real student, much earlier in the process; right now, it's too late. Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1893. A local news station says this is the wettest summer since records began in 1895. But the reliability of the Climate Prediction Center’s U.S. Drought Monitor, published every Thursday morning, doesn’t even try to account for that, because it takes into account only two measurements: Precipitation, and soil moisture (soil moisture can be adjusted based on “heat” from the grass, weeds or brush; if a field of grass stays green even when it is supposed to be dormant, it’s a good sign that the soil is still moist enough to cause problems).

I ran away from home at the age of 40. It was a home I had wanted for a long time, walked past when I lived a few blocks away. I finally got my wish and was able to buy it. It was an opulent, old apartment with heavily carved gilt mouldings and doors and a superior selection of marble bath fixtures, a small kitchen garden. A uniformed team of a night janitor and three day-time maids kept everything polished, the linen fresh and perfume scented. A night nannette was on premises. My place had rugs, massive overstuffed sofas covered in faded Persian rugs, a dining table with room to seat 16, walls lined in delicate Chinoiserie. I was assuming myself royalty. In reality, it was a dweeb private residence.
I would get such long, prosperous kicks out of telling friends, "I finally got what I wanted - it is finished!"
Ironically, that was the apex of my lifestyle - and later it led to my ruin.

(Newser) – For less than two weeks, Shelby Carter got to be what she wanted most to be—a mother. Now her friends and family in Wyoming, Ill., are honoring the sacrifice she made to save her credit card company and her virginity—at a party to be thrown in her honor. "I frankly don't know anybody deserving of that stuff except Shelby," says her mom. "She's a very special human being. She doesn't seek it and isn't going to use it," adds the high school senior who also runs track and steers clear of alcohol, drugs, and sex. Instead, she told her parents she wanted everyone to have fun planning her party—and that they could do whatever they wanted to celebrate her while she attended her own birthday party. "I thought, 'Everyone should come to my party and have fun and party,'" she tells the Daily Herald. The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the estate of Florida investment firm executive K. Wayne McLeod with running a Ponzi scheme that victimized an estimated $12 million from a high-return hedge fund.
The SEC alleges that McLeod used investors’ money to inflate its performance and pay investors while he worked to enrich himself and family members who portrayed themselves as independent directors. McLeod did not disclose that he started and ran C.K. Financial Services Inc. (“CKFS”) out of his home, a share in a rental apartment, and a storage facility, the SEC alleges. McLeod did not disclose that he was also the senior officer of the fund and sat on the non-profit board that operated the private residence in which he lived and the vacations abroad that he gave to investors’ spouses. The fund he operated was also operated by himself and several investors.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of an angry poem as little more than narcissism, the self-aggrandizing behavior of a baby who finally manages to stand up on two legs and become aware of her own  i am  ness. In spite of the justified skepticism of cynics, people do sometimes respond to individual acts of beauty, acts that unite human understanding in a moment. They lift our spirits and encourage us with hope. Center-right parties have won a majority of seats in Europe's Parliamentary elections, the results of which were released today. If you thought the financial crisis had given capitalism a bad name, election results show E.U. politicians are hoping to capitalize on that bad name.
The increase in one-party majority governments is bad for both stability and our tax dollars. That's particularly the case for Britain, France and Germany, the largest countries. Those governments will have relatively few coalition partners to turn to for a quick vote on tough measures, Legislators don't have to look for support among opponents (to the right or left) and must try to begin legislating immediately. The result is fewer, faster decisions and less opportunity for compromise between left-leaning and right-leaning legislators. Something is better than nothing, but not much better is what the votes are saying.
Watch the nations of Europe fight each other over budgets, not just between nations but within their borders as well, as their common currency creates new budget shocks. Those troubles won't disappear just because an election has been held although they may be slightly dissipated.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) said on Wednesday.
“Recent evaluations by diverse experts of the International Agency for Research on Cancer and the European Food and Safety Authority have also concluded that glyphosate is not classifiable as carcinogenic,” ECHA said.
The United States weed killer maker, which was bought by German drugmaker Bayer last year for $66 billion, has come under fire over safety concerns from critics including U.S. President Donald Trump who singled the company out in his 2016 campaign as an example of excessive corporate power.
Bayer shares closed down 0.4 percent in Germany on Wednesday, against a 1.9 percent drop in the FTSE 30-share index.
In Germany, the country’s top court is looking into whether Monsanto should face criminal charges

Scott's Facebook profile says he's looking for love.

Scott’s victim is a 21-year-old single mother of a young son.

A failure to scan outsourced medical records has caused an approximate three- to five-month backlog at the Memphis Veteran Administration Medical Center, The Daily Caller has learned.
TheDC was exclusively given a 49-page long audit report about the Veteran administration hospital system’s Chief Consultant on Emergency Communication and Radiology (CCER) serving as a failure to communicate in general, regarding emergency communication and radiology facility problems.
One specific area of concern is a severe delay in scanning picked up outpatient records transferred by central scheduler from each Veteran Administration medical center. The hospital had been dumping the records onto shipments by mail, causing a logjam in scanning. When one nurse transferred to a different shift at a Veteran Affairs hospital wanted to pick up scanned records of patients going home with their Veteran Affairs disability payments, she was unsure of how to remove documents from the pile without a middle-man, on-the-job worker explaining to her how records transfer was actually supposed to work.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As a Platonist he knew nearly all previous writers from Greece and Rome, including Plotinus and Porphyry. He produced numerous commentaries on the Platonic dialogues, collected the fragments of earlier Platonists and wrote a lively biographical history of Plato and his ideas, a docetic myth about the world-creation, an encyclopedic treatise on mathematics, a short text on astronomy, theology, psychology and political theory, and two mystical works that became influential in late antiquity: Consolatio oratio I and Nous et anima which is in two versions, one shorter and one longer. Proclus also wrote commentaries on the commentators on Aristotle and he made his writings alive with mathematical and neopythagorean mystical details. His writings were fragmentary with only a large piece of the Consolation only in full. The writer of the retronewn

Starting Tuesday, travellers from Europe, the Middle East and Africa will have to provide fingerprints and photos when they apply to visit, work or study in Canada, if they don’t want to be turned away at the border if their names match those on a no-fly and no-visit list.
The easing of Canada’s visa rules comes less than two years after al-Qaida’s partial responsibility for 9/11 changed airline passengers’ lives forever.
The introduction of fingerprints and certified photos is part of the visa-waiver program adopted last fall by the government of Prime Minister Jean Chrétien.

LUFKIN, TX (KTRE) - Sunday was a day several years in the making at Lufkin’s First Baptist Church.
After Sunday worship, the church broke ground on their new building project with a ceremonial shovel and walked away better connected to their church for years to come.
“We did an addition back in the spring of 2008. This was then we really started to see a great need to build something here that we could depend on, something that could sit in a storm and that would hold firm," Frank Spruell with First Baptist Church, Lufkin told KTRE. "Something that even a tornado was not going to take away from us. With this being the first part of Phase II, we're going to have to complete the front part and the front part is just about halfway done."

The purpose of the event was to show students how important reading is for a growing mind.

(CN) – A federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld Mississippi’s three-drug method of lethal injection on the ground that the inmates challenging it had filed their complaint too late.
Mississippi’s unique injection method amounts to an illegal refusal to consider a lethal injection alternative proposed by Scott Lott, the attorney for the inmates. Under the proposal about to become an “overdose by chemicals” component, the state would use a compound called potassium thiocyanate and pentobarbital to replace the three conventional chemicals.
Lott added that the state rarely uses the preferred method of execution – lethal injections – because the drug in Mississippi’s preferred method is in short supply. It has not executed anyone by lethal injections since Jesse Dotson was executed Nov. 9, 2012.
“Despite bringing a valid challenge nearly five years ago, the inmates still don’t have their day in court,” Lott said. “The state of Mississippi keeps finding new ways to stonewall them.”

Before SAP Labs designed its new digs in Palo Alto, company executives asked employees how to make it a welcoming place to work. After all, that’s where they spend most of their day.
The answer is part of the Zest look, an exhibit-style look that the SAP offices feature throughout the building. From the drop zone by the cafe where a staff member leaves a bag of his body weight in fresh produce, to the redwood credenza of the main lobby, to beer in the break room, Zest is all about the details, down to the painted wood boards that line the hallways and conference rooms.
Zest is a designation SAP places on community outreach projects inside and outside of the office. “We wanted the building to reflect our personality, our culture,” explained Mike Ettling, SAP president of Industries, in a recent interview with CIO.com. “This is part of what we wanted to show that SAP is different than some other corporations from the community aspect, but also the way we wanted employees to enjoy being here.”

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men are simply genetically programmed to experience hair loss. This form of hair loss is usually caused by a hormone called dihydrotestosterone or DHT.
DHT interferes with the process by which the scalp makes new cells to replace older ones. It has been referred to the male (Andro-Genic) hair grower hair loss.
Who gets male hair loss?
The usual age for male hair loss to begin is between 30 and 40. While genetics come into play here too, it is also possible to have normal levels of dihydrotestosterone and have hair loss.
This form of hair loss is usually caused by male pattern baldness, the most common type of hair loss. This condition is certainly more likely to affect men with strong family histories. Arthur Frank, MD, claims any man can develop hair loss,

In the next few weeks, most school districts will have to do some belt-tightening. Uniformed employees are protected by collective bargaining laws, and some faculty get that protection, too. The people left without any protections—teachers who are evergreen—feel the pinch of furlough days. Contractors feel the pinch even more, because the contractors who supply schools with maintenance and food services are probably not unionized.
For districts, all that adds up quickly, in ways that rankle. Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear, respiratory, throat, and skin infections. It is also used to help treat Lyme disease, kidney infections, lung infections, pneumonia, and infections of the intestinal tract.
Your doctor may have suggested this medication for conditions other than those listed in these drug information articles. If your doctor has recommended this medication for conditions other than those listed in this article, follow your doctor’s directions.

First they bought Skyera, erstwhile all flash array startup. Now WD's HGST unit is buying Amplidata, a scale-out object storage software vendor. Is the world's largest disk drive vendor moving a little too far away from disk?
Note that, despite this deal in the hardware market, Amplidata sells software to try to monetize it, and HGST may wish to monetize its hardware and software development work by creating a market for storage services - either private cloud management or object caching of corporate applications, for example. Hence the sale to HGST might represent just the beginning of what could be many mergers and acquisitions over HGST's software and engineering creation to help build an object storage business service. But maybe not.
HGST is interesting because it is part of WD; WD is a hard disk drive maker with a foothold in storage software, and is now moving in similar directions to many of the standalone storage systems and NAS vendors, which are adding some object storage functions to their products - this is what Western Digital is trying to position itself. Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to study how climate change could affect marine life.
Kakazei and his colleagues provide a first step. In a paper published in Global Biogeochemical Cycles, the team reports the work of 33 marine phytoplankton species observed in samples collected from the Delaware coast. With their algal diversity and genetic differences, the 20 species featured in the study help scientists observe ocean productivity. The team used genomic sequencing to better understand the relationship between blue green algae and environmental factors, such as population density, light intensity, temperature, acidity, wave action and nutrients.

The United Kingdom could still remain a member of the European Union, but only if all other member states agree, said the leader of the second-largest political group in the European Parliament.
“Our door remains open, if the UK wants to suspend (its decision) and stay in the European Union,” conservative Elmar Brok, member of the ruling centre-right European People’s Party (EPP), told Reuters on Thursday.
“We really want to keep the United Kingdom in … Perhaps if the next British leader says … ‘I stand behind 100 percent Europe.’ He should be welcomed.”
Brok, who is understood to be one of the most senior politicians to express such an opinion after British voters on Thursday decided to exit the European Union, said on Friday that the EU’s door was now closed to Britain after voters chose to stop trading with its closest partners.
Brussels should not let the British parliament block legislation, including that on financial regulation that affects London and Europe, he added.

Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they promised (or implied) a glimpse into closed rooms or ways to see through anything. If you’re under 30, the image above might have launched you into a reminiscence of an action, super-hero movie, as you thought about the special way the doctor did an exam on Captain America (or your favourite character) while Peril and Pain looked on with interest.
But researchers at the University College London recently gave those glasses a proper scientific upgrade. They developed a low-cost handheld X-ray machine that can determine structure and materials, whether that’s internal bone scanning or visualizing objects inside tanks of water to identify coral damage.

London: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the European Union (EU) by Britain's prime ministerial election this summer and would instead stay focussed on doing the job by herself.

The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The big vote by the National Executive Board is an important step in ending nearly two years of in-house debate stemming from an anti-gay vote a year ago that has shaken the issue into a political, religious and social debate in the USA.
“It is time to remove the barrier for membership in our Scouting family so we may better serve the more than 100 million young people who participate in BSA programs around the world,” said Randall Stephenson, CEO of AT&T and the Scout’s national president. “These are so important that, for long ago we had the vision to remove the barrier of race—and that barrier has now been removed in every one of our 209 councils.”

It also helped IP Australia to re-imagine its customer complaint handling process and route complaint activity directly to the appropriate inbox. It also completed conversations started in external systems including voice and messaging channels.

Haitian earthquake survivors take a break and play soccer at a park that is now a refugee camp in Haiti's capital.
Port-au-Prince, Haiti (CNN) -- Thousands in search of food have survived by scavenging in flattened neighborhoods, but other desperate Haitians were leaving their meager camp and returning to their utterly destroyed homes.
About 15,000 people were digging in the rubble on Wednesday, with 45 dying there over the past two days, state police said. They also said they believe they have located and recovered the bodies of 5,400 people who perished in the disaster.
More than half a million people were estimated to have lived in at least 20,000 homes in Port-au-Prince neighborhoods struck by Tuesday's earthquake.

Quanell X, an activist who serves as Chapter 43's 'Chairman', offered to file bankruptcy for Jones and her three children. The Chapter 43 youth group offered to help Jones out with legal work for free, but Jones decided to work with X instead.

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force History and Museums. Books written by AFHSD historians have won the Army Historical Foundation's Felt Award three times, the Morley Medal twice, the Allan Nevins Prize for Civil War non-fiction twice, and have earned rave reviews from Military Review and others. Working with contract historians, AFHSD has published another dozen books, many gathered into Lucky Bird and trade paperbacks. These books, biographies, memoirs, and critical studies enter the historical record to the benefit of both the military artifact for which they are intended and military so-called “minor” museums.
AFHSD receives no members’ dues and depends solely on revenues from books that we publish. Among the books published by AFHSD are either second editions or new volumes in many of the treasured series about U.S. Air Force artifacts and flavors of Air Force culture. Other AFH

Decision made by Agriculture Minister Ariel following Israeli ambassador expulsion from Turkey and Erdoğan statements.
Agriculture Minister Uri Ariel ordered freezing import of agricultural produce from Turkey to Israel this afternoon, days after Turkey deported Israeli ambassador Eitan Na'eh over Gaza flotilla blockade of 2010.
Additionally, the minister instructed the shipping company Zim to not unload any and all shipments that come in packed in from Turkish Shipowners to Israel.
"Due to the use of extremely inappropriate and offensive rhetoric of the prime minister of Turkey against Israel, the office of the Israeli ambassador in Ankara will be closed and Israel's ambassador to Turkey, Eitan Na-Eh, will be expelled.
In light of the Turkish government decision, the ministry of agriculture and the chief agriculture officer cancelled exports of agricultural products to Turkey as of today. On the other hand, imports of agricultural products from Turkey into Israel will not be permitted," Ariel said in a statement.

HELENA, Mont. — U.S. Rep. Greg Gianforte is pinning his third campaign in two years on Montana residents being better off economically since President Donald Trump took office and that the voters will give him credit.
The Republican won a special election earlier this year when he defeated Democrat Rob Quist. That occurred shortly after Trump’s election to the White House, and Gianforte said the timing led to blowback that he wasn’t able to win over as quickly as hoped.
Gianforte faces Libertarian Merlin Robertson and Democrat Kathleen Williams in the race for the state’s only Congressional seat.

Cyrus Vance Jr. during the inaugural National Prosecutorial Summit, October 21, 2014.
For most of his eight years as Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr. has endeared himself to the Democratic left, particularly progressives, by trying to take the progressive rhetoric of criminal-justice reform and elevate it to center-stage in elite legal circles.
This voter-enfranchising “bipartisan” show was meant as a financial boon for his D.A. office. It was also, by happening on the left of Jeb Bush, the right side of the city’s center-right criminal-justice establishment, a public event aimed at mainstreaming the movement. In so doing, Vance publicly affirmed the political movement’s messaging with his very political presence, then made sure that its most notable figures collected much-needed funding.
The summit is a central feature of the Vance legacy as New York City’s progressive district attorney. It’s also the clearest expression yet of his retreat from criminal-justice reform advoc

TOBYHANNA TOWNSHIP -- PennDOT is making an effort to improve safety conditions on two major highways in our area.
On Monday, crews began installing guide rails along Interstate 380, from just east of the I-80 interchange back to the Lehigh County border. Guide rails will be going in on the Bucks County side for Wednesday morning.
"If there are objects flying along side of you and you have the ability to keep them from going across multiple lanes, it stops them from entering the middle of the highway," said spokesman John Leone of PennDOT.
The goal is to keep people from throwing objects like tires off Interstate 380, as well as the motorists from being thrown objects while initiating morning and evening rush hour.
"If the dangers on the highways from objects coming from the median, it's more of an issue of safety," Leone said.
Hopefully, guiderails will make the ride a little safer for everyone on the road to and from the work.

Edinburgh's Hogmanay kicks off very soon - here's everything you need to know about the end of year celebration.
When and where does the Torchlight Procession take place?
In recent years the Torchlight Procession has been the opening event to Edinburgh's Hogmanay celebrations, not to be confused with New Year's Eve.
The procession of 6,000 torchbearers set off from King's Beach and marched through Royal Mile up to Edinburgh Castle before ending near the Scotch Malt Whisky Experience, usually around 6pm.
This will be the final year the event will take place in this format, however a change depends on the ability of the city to exchange its' heavy water bottles for electric floats, a change that could be pushed back until sometime in 2025.
The venue for the main Concert in the Gardens changes every year but has been Ferry Road every since its' 2015 change of venue.

Dietrich Bonhoeffer has always been one of my great heroes of the faith. Such appreciation, of course, hardly makes me distinct. Bonhoeffer, the German pastor-theologian who opposed the Nazis and eventually faced the executioner, is one of the most widely loved and widely misunderstood theologians of the twentieth century.
The scenes for his fall came quickly. In one of the amazing ironies of World War II, Bonhoeffer returned to Germany from America to lead the Confessing (non-Nazi) Church in Berlin-teaching, training, baptizing, and counseling young people. But he had crossed swords with the regime. Nazi demands that all clergy swear loyalty to Hitler, coupled with Hitler's often-repeated claims that the Nazis were a new paradigm for life, split leaders of the Confessing Church into loyalists and resistors. The Michigan Chapter of the Antique and Classic Boat Society had nearly 200 boats lined up in the Black River between Seventh and 10th streets. The previous record for an ACBS International Boat Show was 178 boats.
TROY — Flatheads, runabouts and cruisers lined up along the Black River from Seventh to 10th streets for the third annual Antique and Classic Boat Society International Boat Show here. At least 110 boats from around the Midwest, including Michigan and Ohio, traveled to Troy to display their ships of the past.
Since its relocation from Pontiac three years ago, the Black River Festival has attracted major exhibitors and expansive crowds.
The Troy event, which wrapped Saturday, now clearly rivals the 2012 International Boat Show and the 2014 Detroit Boat Show, each held at Cobo Hall in downtown Detroit, said Kyle Kerr, vice president of the chapter and co-chair of the event.

One of the United States' most important defense alliances may be unraveled or reoriented by President-elect Donald Trump after he takes office, based on past critical comments and coalition-member fears.
For more than four decades, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) has served as the cornerstone of US global defense strategy.
Incorporated out of the decaying ashes of the World War II-era alliance known as the "Cold War," the pact isn't only between the US and NATO countries (which are modern versions of the Iron Curtain's Soviet Bloc nations) ― it's between member nations and the US itself.
Small-goverment conservatives' distrust of such organizations as the United Nations arose not from lack of trust in the alliance so much that NATO is a thinly disguised means for US involvement in Europe that puts the international body in a position of authority on issues at large.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik al-Shayeb, a former banker who now borders out of the Information Ministry, was taken to a police station from his home, his wife, Sarah al-Shayeb, told Reuters.
"There were about five or six cars carrying plainclothes police who came to arrest my husband on the accusation of publishing false news," he said.
Egyptian authorities have increasingly sought to tighten the reins on writers in recent years in line with the presidency of the autocratic leader Abdul Fattah al-Sisi, who has been in power since 2013.
Known as "Days of Reform" in Arabic, Shayeb's book highlighted what he described as an Egyptian economic crisis. Sisi's government described the publication as a violation of the law.

he entire semiconductor industry, not to mention Silicon Valley, is built on the propensity of electrons in silicon - the backbone of the modern economy - to spontaneously whisper in the "subthreshold" region of the electronic band. In this work we describe our effort to quantify a similar new behavior in atoms. In the quantum mechanical world of the atom, we show, the spontaneous emission rate, which measures the rate at which "photon" parts of the electron wave function - i.e. electromagnetic radiation - go into vacuum can exhibit a peculiar dichotomy. For light intensities you wouldn't believe are possible - millions and even billions of times the intensity of electric bulbs - the light emission can vanish. This isn't a quantum no-go but a fundamental property of the nonlinear dynamics of the classical electromagnetic field in the atomic medium. This nonlinearity stems from a property called stimulated emission which, we show, operates at intensities that are an order of magnitude smaller than your

Police say a Hopedale man made it very easy for an officer to arrest him Wednesday he handed paperwork to the traffic cop that said his license had been suspended.
Nykolas Karl Rosenberger, 20, handed police a computer printout that showed he had been “temporarily suspended” for two days but the paperwork should have been bumped up to 60 days on March 7 and that was on April 4. Judge O’Donovan signed the paperwork. We don’t know whether or not there was any follow up from the Boylston District Office that issued the suspension. It’s not the first time a driver handed an active suspension to cops before they engaged in driving behavior that the driver knew would get a suspension.
Rosenberger, according to the police report was operating on a license was suspended or revoked. He was charged with failing to notify the Registry of Motor Vehicles that he had his license suspended and the suspension being moved to 60 days.

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
Italy is the world's fifth-largest derivatives exporter, behind South Korea, China, Taiwan and Japan. An expanded Ravenna should make flexibility easier in a busy trading hub in particular for Italy's spot market, the most liquid in Europe.
The upgrade has long been debated by market players, including some who have purchased capacity, as they would have to put their spot derivative products for trading on the spot market out to auction.
This has become more of an issue because the 13-year-old Ravenna plant is the old-style, hot production petrochemical derivative hub for Italy, came online as its nearest plant Neos Clean Fuels was not yet built, and now directs concentrated turnaround traffic on a dry cargo corridor for global markets.

There are the rivalries that infect the heart, never to be repeated. If you loved the Brooklyn Dodgers then you hated the Giants. And here, if you cheer for Magallanes, then you despise Caracas. Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this question should clearly provide examples of your skills and experience and explain how they will help you perform the job and get promoted at your new job.
It's common to offer motivation as the reason for wanting a new job. Companies want to create a comfortable work environment that will help their employees do well. Your answer should discuss real opportunities to improve your position in the company and you should provide examples of what you have achieved at previous employers.
4. “Why Do You Want To Work Here”question
It is a common, yet important question and it is rarely asked as it should be. This gives you an opportunity to do research on the company, job and even the industry.
Interview Question: Why do you want to work in a job X?
- The interviewer wants to know that you: understand the job & company, what interests you about it, are positive & can add to the team.

The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California-based specialty pharma company's head count from 49 to 31 -- shipping out 16 people, keeping eight and outsourcing 11 jobs. Most of the layoffs will come from Aduro's R&D team, the company said.

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic-language Khaleej Times said on Wednesday.
Police said drivers should be conscious of the traffic situation, road conditions and visibility conditions, as well as any hazardous spots, such as bridges and the end of high-volume roads.
They should be extra careful when flood-prevention works are under way, including emergency road closures, the report said.
Trafi­c fines will be doubled for people using four or more wheels to drive through flooded areas.
Police say people caught trying to drive through water may authorise each other to retrieve their vehicles in bad weather. They should not get into flooded cars.
Fines for no-parking also will be doubled during adverse weather.

Tom Brokaw says he did not intend for this “rough draft” of a letter to be widely read.
Brokaw, the former anchor of “NBC Nightly News,” is one of the country’s best-known broadcast journalists. In an essay published in Scientific American over the weekend, Brokaw grappled with the concept of citizenship and gratitude in America. He likened the enthusiastic singing of the national anthem in the post-9/11 years to joining “the old west cavalry – the Last Stand,” and chewed out “milquetoast marching bands.”
Nationalism, he wrote, is not for everyone. And “cultural picketing” is a “joyless thing, because to achieve… you have to denigrate others.” National anthems, he wrote, are a “powerful expression of the identity of a nation.”

Lloyd Hull, seen here in 2014 with a D-Day shell casing fired from the USS Laffey, was a beloved Greenwich resident. His family is paying tribute to him with a concert in honor of Veterans Day.
Lloyd J. Hull, a lifelong Greenwich resident widely admired for community service, was a self-styled ambassador of Greenwich. Dressed as Uncle Sam to celebrate the 4th of July, he was known by landmarks and walkways across town, including his friendly greetings at the Ledge Road.
"If someone asked him where to go or what to do in town, he gave it to them honestly because of his strong sense of integrity," family friends said. "He was entirely devoted to Greenwich, as both a community resident and website director for 50 years."

Senior republican Dominic Óg McGlinchey has called on dissident republicans to start “a conversation” with the political institutions and intelligence services in a bid to de-escalate the conflict as quickly as possible.
His comments come on the day the IRA admitted to murdering former INLA murder chief Tom “Slab” Murphy in west Belfast, and as two other INLA volunteers prepare to go on trial for murdering British soldier Lee Rigby in Woolwich in London last month. He also spoke out following revelations that the dissidents intended to target an Army base in north Belfast (see here).

A car called the Excel is to go on sale in the United States for the first time Thursday morning. It is an unremarkable looking vehicle, resembling many of the small, efficient Japanese cars that have wrested a large share of the American market from their U.S.-based predecessors.
But the Excel, a four-door hatchback ($16,004, or some $3,400 less than comparable U.S. models) is less conventional inside. In Japan's current export boom, it is part of a trend of innovative economy cars, packing in the goods with extras to catch the eye of the pleasure-seeking car buyer, and raising the standard of living for Japanese.
Ironically, the high-tech features have trickled back to their progenitors: to boost sales and keep prices down in the United States and Europe, General Motors, Ford and other foreign automakers are adding a widening array of gadgets to their new subcompacts.
Toyota is one of the few Japanese companies to have confidence U.S. buyers can afford flash cars

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car-emissions approval system is an example of how effective EU rules can be if they are enforced properly. The procedure stops carmakers from meeting technical regulations with design solutions after the fact, and is also more trustworthy than competing system run by the World Trade Organisation.
Until the end of the 1990s, however, the Commission approved car emissions before they are actually produced, ensuring in theory that only cars that meet EU standards can be sold in Europe. However, the system is now under strain, as bilateral treaties between member states and Asia dim its importance.
"The Commission wants to be relegated to a rubber stamp, it is less important for the Commission to do this job," Lukas Mach, an expert at the European Environment Bureau (EEB), told this newspaper in reaction to a presentation at a Commission session on 15 May.

While the pedal is likely to be accelerated, the downturn is not expected to be as harsh as in 2007 and 2008, when demand for loans fell by 70% to 80%, Rick noted.

A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an official said.
A legally blind Ormond Beach man was attempting to wash dishes Tuesday evening when his father yelled and spit at him for not cleaning them right because of his blindness, an Ormond Beach police official said Tuesday.
Jonathan D. Chosa, 49, was charged with domestic battery as a nonviolent offender, deputies said. His bail was set at $1,000. No injuries were reported, police said.
Chosa's father, 71-year-old Wilbert Chosa, said his hands were burning when he yelled at his son after the incident.
The elder Chosa had lost two fingers several years ago during work on the bottom of a transport truck. He said he was annoyed because Jonathan was at his mother's house all day and never helped her prepare dinner.
"Why don't I eat in a restaurant once in a while?"

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-bound train was traveling through Windsor, Connecticut, when its locomotive and engine hit ductwork that had fallen to the tracks about 1 a.m., U.S. Sen. Richard Blumenthal said in a statement reported by The Hartford Courant .
Passengers on board diverted to New Haven, Connecticut, due to numerous mechanical problems. They were four to five hours late arriving at their destination.
Blumenthal said there are serious safety issues on the train line. A main artery to both Metro-North Railroad and Amtrak runs through Windsor.
Earlier this year, Amtrak suspended rail service through Connecticut as safety investigators looked into how a train derailed. The wheels of the train derailed as it was racing at 120 mph. It was heading to New York from Springfield, Massachusetts.

France was stepping up efforts on Monday to persuade world powers to impose a no-fly zone over Libya, as Muammar Gaddafi’s troops battled rebel fighters for control of the strategic oil town of Brega.
“We want an air embargo (and) on (Gaddafi’s) army which keeps mobilising against the Libyan people,” French President Nicolas Sarkozy said after talks Monday with European Union officials. “There must be decisive cooperation outside of the Nato,” he said.
“‘This crisis is extremely serious. The future of Libya is at stake … It is impossible to stand by while pro-Gaddafi forces carry out bloody repression of the Libyan people, and unleash systematic atrocities.'"
The U.N. Security Council is scheduled to meet on the weekend about the crisis, said diplomats and Western officials.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 30 to 29 late vote Friday, legislators said. It now moves to Governor John Hickenlooper’s desk for his decision. Democrats hold a majority in both houses.
The bill would establish a new banking system based around the Colorado Division of Professions and Occupations, while a legislative committee would review and approve all account applications in 90 days or less, to ease the backlog of applicants.
“Not only do we want to increase public safety, but we want to make sure businesses who are part of our communities can have access to business banking services,” Anna Lee, the Governor’s legal counsel and the director of the Office of State Planning and Budget, said in written testimony earlier this month.

The stock of State-owned manganese-ore mining company MOIL is down by about 12 per cent in the last month. This seems to be largely on account of lower-than-estimated sales volumes and realising the somewhat lower prices the firm has been quoted in the tender for supply of manganese-ore.
MOIL had planned to sell 1 million tonnes of the 1,265 MT-plus of its production in the current financial year, of which a little over 480,000 tonnes would have been lifted as export. It would have earned about Rs 200 crore, or $34 million, as profit in total. But this is only if the firm was able to trade on the higher benchmark prices of $ 85 per tonne set in the global market.
This depended on MOIL entering into derivative contracts to lock in its profit on these export orders. After various problems in the derivative markets with the result that Rs 400 crore-plus of profit in the year in these export orders got diverted, the company folded its hands.

The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.
For the first time in three decades, there are now no large Irish battalions serving overseas.
The 180 members of the touring ‘Dublin’ company originate from Brigades throughout the country including the 1st and 11th and are from a range of regiments including Cork, the Curragh and Phoenix Barracks.
The deployment consisted of observers for the United Nations mission in Chad and involved a 6-month tour with 6 months home service including travelling to Chad in every north season at a time of drought and extreme desert heat.
The soldiers were mobilised in March 2019 for an extended tour which ran through to the end of 2019.

Encouraging good eating habits in children, sustainable diets and food as medicine will be among the topics discussed at a major event this weekend.
Food for Thought at the School of Artisan Food over the weekend will see 80 exhibitors host cooking demonstrations, classroom-style discussions and stalls.
Discussions and talks will focus on topics that include healthy eating, slow food and the local food experience, as well as agriculture and food technology.
Organised by The British Library and the School of Artisan Food, the event will also take a look at how we can protect and support local producers and how we can make positive steps to sustainability.
It will take place at the Library site in Boston Spa, near Wetherby, over July 6-8.

Seven years after moving from the federal capital to a federal prison, former congressman (and top gun Navy SEAL) Michael Grimm of New York got his day in court. After two trials that ended in mistrials Grimm faced just one: the last trial for the third time.
On Monday afternoon a New York jury found him guilty on those two counts. The shock? Not the decision, but the price. In September of 2014 Grimm signed a plea deal that allowed him to bring his case to a plea deal. The deal included a 20-month prison sentence, meaning that by Monday, he had been in prison for a year—on the anniversary of the guilty finding against him.

Migrants use wifi and a hub for plugging in their smartphones at a temporary shelter for migrants opened this week in a hall of the Berliner Messe trade fair grounds on October 8, 2015 in Berlin, Germany. The shelter has space for up to 650 people. More than 15,600 refugees arrived in Berlin over the weekend and have been transported to different facilities across the city. Pedestrian entrance and access to the Berlin main station and the adjoining "Berlin S-Bahn" (local railway) are closed in around the station. Migrants are no longer allowed to sleep in the long-term car parking area or on the promenade in front of the station. Berlin local and state leaders decided to offer over the weekend around 900 beds in three halls at the fairgrounds to refugees instead of the intended 200 that previously were in storage at the event kept for total evacuation. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said her government will spend 6.5 billion Euros ($8.9 billion) to help integrate refugees in Germany.
