Vicki Denton, who on vacation to Orlando from Ohio, perused items in the gift shop at Hollywood Studios when the alleged incident occurred in 2016.
A woman who contends she was injured after being struck with a water bottle at Disney World in Orlando has been given a Dec. 17, 2016 trial on the lawsuit she filed against the company.
Vicki Denton, of Sidney, Ohio, says she was headed to the bathroom at the American Eagles Theater at Walt Disney World Resort when her backrest of the seat was struck by an unknown Disney security guard with a 12-ounce water bottle. The impact forced her to sit forward and nearly ejected her from the seat. The security guard later apologized.
Seeking damages of more than $15,000, Denton says Disney knew the security guard had been relieved of keeping a seat overloaded with liquor bottles. Security guards typically are trained to avoid leaving alleged contraband in a designated area for the public, the suit states.

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau's office said that, contrary to assertions by the hotels that homeless people sleeping in hallways were not afflicted by bedbugs, the company, Intertab, trained pest-control workers to strip hotels and sets of bunk beds of mattresses contaminated with them. The mattresses and bedding usually were not disinfected or destroyed and later were returned to the stockpiles, with the bedbugs intact, it was said.
The hotel executives highlighted in the indictment are Frank Escalante, vice president of the company, and James Pratt, director of pest-control operations. Mr. Escalante, 41, of Jersey City, N.J., was on vacation, a spokeswoman for the company said, and Mr. Pratt, 45, of White Plains, was not available for comment

Donald Bren, chairman of the Irvine Co.
Job: Sole owner, chairman of The Irvine Co.
Bio: He is the wealthiest U.S. real estate mogul, with a fortune valued at $101. This year is his 20th as the company’s top executive. It’s where his services company, Advanced Mobility & Diagnostics Systems, moved from Santa Ana in 2012. Asked if he’s ever ending a day thinking how to make his money grow even bigger, Bren replied, “I don’t think that ever leaves my mind. So that’s 24/7.”
Bren is also: A licensed pilot, a resident of San Francisco, an owner of the Newport Beach Lidos and Honorary Advisor of the Asia-Pacific Policy Forum.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful of clients at a time. To meet higher demand from clients, smaller companies may rent server resources from larger vendors. As a result, reseller hosting companies rent server space from larger providers and resell that space to smaller companies. Instead of renting physical space on the provider's server, you will be essentially reselling the provider's services to potential clients. Reseller hosting has grown in popularity over the years in part because of the time, technology and resources required to operate a web-hosting business. With web hosting services, the city in which your clients are located can affect the time it takes to rent server resources. If the company is based in the Midwest, for example, it may take two or three hours for a change to take effect if clients are using servers that are sold in another city. Successful resellers can charge more for their services and have the money

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – or the number of babies who do not live after the first 28 days after birth – has declined 25 percent since 2005.
For Syracuse residents, and many residents in and around Upstate, the good news is the dramatic declines in this public health metric that were seen from 2005 up until 2014. Then again, there was – on almost every district level metric – a pause in the decline.
The upcoming year or so could determine the fate of where Syracuse and Utica stand on the track record of reducing newborn mortality. (CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “spindle cells” work on damaged DNA before it becomes dangerous. The discovery may help scientists fight back against cancer as well as other public health concerns, such as the Zika virus.
“Spindle cells” act like excavators, the scientists said. They search for and destroy unwanted DNA sequences before they can become cancerous or prevent a child from being born.
ABC News reports about scientists saying that elephants will live 100 years old.
The spindle cell breakthrough made worldwide news in 2015, when scientists at Oregon State University uncovered the elephant cells’ ability to target deadly Alzheimer’s, four years earlier.

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemicals at a time when they cost more and have become a rarer commodity. It helps with water conservation, a time-honored value in arid climates. In urban and suburban settings, it often reorients backyards and gardens in a spirit-lifting way that renew our connection to the land.

Home Procurement News Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't tracking your money properly, for example, you might inadvertently overlook discrepancies or other symptoms of irregularity or fraud. Your Purchase to Pay (P2P) group plays a critical role in this area, using lean methodologies to handle transactions. Once you apply lean accounting, you won't just spend less money - you might also uncover areas that indicate a need to streamline processes.
A difficult problem to solve
To use lean methods, companies often need to subject specific portions of their supply chain to lean assessments. This involves a deep dive into specific areas, allow you to help identify and rectify weak links in your brand. This itself may be hard enough, but if your supply chain is funded by resources that aren't allocated evenly throughout – for instance, if your P2P team lacks the idea of lean or a similar incredible knowledge – this might be even more difficult to solve.

It takes a lot to make me feel ashamed of London, my beloved home city. But yesterday’s tower-block inferno did it. The raging fire at Grenfell Tower in North Kensington, the disturbing image of families leaping from high windows to escape the flames, the sheen of mournful difficulty in the eyes of the local bishop as he fought to console his flock …
My private London is a place of homey comfort and familiarity – the well-trodden paths of Brompton and Battersea Parks, to this or that coffee shop where I may meet a friend, the comfort in a Mothercar that ferries me around the inner west of the city, a stubby of a local microbrew at a Real Ale pub near where I reside. In public my persona is one of the close familiar in show business and, if needed, the political figure. My home is a place of constant spectacle; my office a place of distraction. I hope that, in public, I have learned to wear diplomacy with the grace God bestowed upon me.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter, Halina Karnow, a food writer in England.
Karnow had been one of the anchors of the PBS show “Frontline” since its launch in 1983. In four decades of journalism, he wrote from six continents, with and without press ties. He served as Washington bureau chief of the International Herald Tribune and as Asia editor for Hearst News Syndicate. He contributed to newspapers, magazines and other publications, including the Wall Street Journal and the Washington Post.
His books include reports on the Philippines, South Vietnam, Iran and other subjects, along with a biography, page-by-page, of John F. Kennedy’s “Profiles in Courage,” the 1956 Pulitzer-prize winner

Batu Api is the name commonly used for the native dances performed at weddings. by both cultures and have now become the norm. In traditional Bornean and Brunei culture, for example, fire dancing was an art long practiced and valued for its entertainment and symbolism. The ceremony includes throwing fire at the water to purify it and the smoke is tamed with water and sunshine for purification. In Brunei, Bejalai means “stamp dance”. Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals identify which options, or the methods behind those options, are most effective at achieving a certain end objective – much like a flowchart, information flow diagram, or a mapping of logical steps.
Decision trees are heavily based on a cost/benefit analysis, and identify multiple elements on which someone’s decision will be based. Trees can be put together by one person, a team or even the public via a survey questionnaire.
Decision trees have a distinct look to them – a set of branches forming a tree-like shape that guides you to an appropriate decision or outcome – but other flow charts have slightly different usage and looks.
Decision trees are used in an array of fields, including project management, business analysis, customer relationship management and others. So how can the application of these decision trees be improved?
Clarity rather than accuracy is a goal we should strive for while diagnosing problems with decision tree

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, the northern state of Kachin on Saturday, bringing houses down with it.
Police say that among the approximately 400 residences and community huts hit, 59 houses collapsed and almost no unharmed survivors were found.
"It is possible that the jade-miners had been buried under the landslide, but the exact number is yet to be determined," said regional police Lieutenant General Tun Tun Naing, according to the official Global New Light of Myanmar.
Stories of windfalls and staggering profits are common in Hpakant — fabled primarily as a jade-mining centre.
But most who rush into mining without proper protective cover die young or chronically ill after spending decades exposed to toxic chemicals buried in the violent soil.

Taipei, July 18 (CNA) U.S.-based search engine giant Google on Wednesday launched a new Google Maps service for motorbike riders in Taiwan that will help them plan their routes and calculate their journey times on the move.
The service can be accessed via the Google Maps Taiwan website, Google Maps mobile app, and Google Assistant.
By simply searching road configurations on Google Maps, motorbike riders can browse a list of popular routes and suggested roads according to their purposes, which helps them to plan and customize the routes. In addition, they can compare different routes, take into account lunchtime and dining places, and take note of the distance of the routes from their departures.
Last but not least, the Google Maps Map for bikers allows riders access to timetables of the city bus, high speed rail and Taiwan Railways on the same page so they can figure on their schedules and tap into their bus schedules when they want to go home.
Aside from Taiwan, the service is available in four other Southeast Asian nations -- Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines -- through their Google Maps website

Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2015. Outside of a handful of people who knew him, he made no impact on the larger world. Were it not for his contributions to experimental music and art, he mightn’t even have made an impression in the afterlife either. Instead Maloney lived—and died—as Pat Maloney, an anonymous understated life. In sickness he remained tolerably stoic. In health he was not particularly cheerful. Now he’s buried beneath a copy of Einstein’s Collected Works. With a few detours and a sense of distance, his path was undeniably short despite being a grand one: he played in bands, he worked on a computer, he collaborated with theatre professionals and helped bring their art into being. But it was always art as a preface to action, an activity or pursuit he described as “the lifestyle of an artist.” Amen.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
The study, published this week in the open journal PLOS ONE, compared 75 grandmothers who spent an evening in Brazil relaxing with their grandchildren with 75 grandmothers in the United States. Participants were 63 years old on average and classified their health, both physical and mental, as "excellent."
Both groups were asked to identify their best "fuse moment." Fuse, the authors explain, is the amount of time it takes a person to go from being upset to angry. This measurement is considered to be an indicator of self-control. Participants also filled out questionnaires and were given a series of means to identify their stress levels. The grandmothers in Brazil spent time significantly less than their U.S. counterparts - about 30 minutes less (about 11 fuses).

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2011. The company is now focusing on the improvements it made while maintaining efficiency and performance.
Historically Hive users have been frustrated that, as the job gets more complex, the job's performance degrades. Without parallelizing this performance begins to degrade exponentially with each task added to the query. Stinger changes this by allowing Hive jobs to exist in a world of separated instances of parallel Hive, opting in at any time, as they do now micromanage resource pooling.
The changes make it possible to have managed instances of Hadoop that get config changes to specify resource base configurations, and accepting those configurations in these worlds of parallel Hive. This new scheme allows admins or the developers of the configured machine to keep Hive from being the bottleneck that causes the query to slow.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given. But what about small and midsized businesses? What opportunities exist to automate core backoffice and sales-order processing functions if there are few, if any, open-source ERP tools?
OpenMFG, the first application to be based on the MySQL open-source database suggested by the open-source Apache Web server, is beginning to fill that void. The development team of Jet Force Software Inc. of Miami, Floridaa privately held firmis making available to potential customers its first public beta release this week.
Despite the name, OpenMFG is, in fact, an Internet-enabled suite that automates the production process in a lean manufacturing environment. OpenMFG includes a management dashboard, order-processing and scheduling, quality-control management, and shop-floor support.

NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — Treasury prices extended their pullback Tuesday, propelling the government debt market to its fourth day of losses in five sessions, after data showed service-sector companies expanded at a stronger pace in March than at any point since the start of the year, intensifying investor concerns about revival of the economy data showed.
“We saw some weaker data,” particularly in manufacturing, that caused investors to take some money out of Treasurys and put it into riskier assets such as U.S. equities, said Richard Moody, chief economist with Regions Financial. “There may be a muted reaction but they are looking at the end of the run to better growth” in the spring and summer.
The benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 19/32 of a point, or $2.12 in price, to 97 19/32, with yields up at 2%. German bonds, which tend to have a large effect on the U.S. market, gained, directing yields lower in the debt based here.

When I moved to Seattle this past summer to start my journey in the Communication Leadership graduate program at the University of Washington, one of the first things my newfound classmates said to me was, “You’ll definitely see the homeless.”
I was fairly certain they were attempting a joke.
But as the days, months, and seasons passed, the serious realities of Seattle’s homeless population became more and more apparent to me. And, as my new classmates predicted, I did begin to see them more and more.
I soon became a regular at a familiar spot right around the corner from my apartment on Capitol Hill, Seattle’s densely populated LGBTQ+ neighborhood. Nestled among the many brunch spots, glitzy hotspots, and chic coffee shops, people and tents seem to fit softly into this neighborhood despite its rather glaring contrast to its surroundings.
We have been taught to only look at someone as a singular person.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the National Defense Authorization Act which dramatically expands the definition of "spouse" to include individuals in a same-sex marriage entered in a jurisdiction where such marriages are legal under state law. This law also states that employees will have FMLA leave available to them due to active duty capability. Under the amendment, the spouse will now include an individual in a same-sex marriage, even if the married couple resides in a state that bans same-sex marriage. If the individual works for an employer of 50 or more employees, the individual has the right to receive 12 weeks of leave not only for their own health, but could extend their leave to their spouse or child. Pardoned by the Pope but shunned by the English, the betrayal by John Soulis, Richard of Gloucester marched on Scotland with a huge force from England in a bid to regain the independence for Scotland that had started two decades earlier at Bannockburn.
Robert the Bruce is remembered for his legendary quote about not retreating down a long grassed, uphill deserted path with the only man to fight alongside him giving him permission if he wished to go.

"They have an appreciation for what's beyond their Disneyland."
The grandparents that Morris, Standing und Consol spoke about are Billie Diamond's.
Born Hilda Adele Buhrowsky, she had grandchildren who vividly described her as kindhearted and wildly adventurous.
They spoke of plunges in duck blinds with handmade duck calls for decoys and of her swimming and skin diving, trekking throughout the Everglades, Florida's version of the Yukon.
They talked of her babysitting them on the couch, of the Cub Scout-Camp fire roasting marshmallows and frogs' eyes in the backyard.

Sunday will be the 42nd annual Earth Day celebration. Here are four facts about Earth Day to help you to celebrate.
President Jimmy Carter established the first Earth Day in 1970. It was part of the 60th anniversary of the April 22 birthday of revolutionary Vladimir Lenin. In 1970, the idea was to try to harness the power of the protest movement for the environment, according to Sol Metropole, the organizer of the first Earth Day in Washington, D.C. After the Watergate scandal broke, one of the first big stories about President Nixon was his decision to shut down the EPA, according to Metropole's 2009 memoir, Earth Day: A Concise Guide. How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you will in their rules. This allows them to identify, initiate, and execute good trades based on the chart. This makes sense, as these are the signposts with benign, meaningful, and profitable entries.
Successful traders however have learned it is also extremely important (arguably, more important) in this internet marketing hypersensitive environment to enforce a profitable exit. This is especially the case for options traders that collect premiums (options terminal mark-overs are of my most concern). It is equally important for traders using a levered futures account. Margins can be lost in minutes in the wrong futures market. This challenge is surprisingly underestimated by traders who, with 3 to 4 non-equity discretionary markets, struggle with enticing those kids on the cover of Forbes to pay them proper respect.

Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, published pictures of uranium level 4 centrifuges at the site in Natanz some 200 kilometers (140 miles) south of the capital, Tehran.
Iran announced the site that has been operating below ground since spring, saying all of its centrifuges at the site will operate under one roof and in a single hall once fully operational.
State media reported that the additional mill, a part of Natanz, was built with nearly $12 million in tax revenues and that France-based Framatome provided all technical services in this project. ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating efforts to win approval for a merger with U.S. peer T-Mobile US Inc (TMUS.N).
Andrea Aurelio, the U.S.-Swedish investor who holds about 64 percent of the voting rights to Sunrise (SRCG.S), said the seven-month deadline set to decide on any capital increase was "strictly too short".
He argued in a letter to Sunrise that the government favored extending the deadline by at least two years to support a merger that has yet to win the backing of the Swiss Department of Economic Affairs.
Sunrise Chief Executive Andrew Halls told Reuters in January that the company expected to apply for a capital hike by the end of the first quarter, in order for the shareholder vote to happen before October.

Dr. Narges Bani Asadi says cancer is a genetic disease, and she is using technology to fight it.
Asadi is the founder and CEO of Bina, a healthcare startup working to make ‘personalized radiotherapy’ on a smartphone. This is a simple and portable X-ray scanning device to let you have needle-free radiation therapy in your own home, doctor’s office and emergency room.
Currently, 19 million people and their families benefit from radiation therapy each year worldwide. To them comes a ray of hope in Asadi’s smartphone-based scanning system. Bina’s first beta totally automated mobile device can generate an image of tumors in patients in about five minutes, delivers a process doctors widely consider to be effective in minimizing cancer and disease spread in patients.

Star Washington Wizards guard Gilbert Arenas, 28, appeared in the D.C. Superior Court to be sentenced for the gun crime he admitted to in January. He has been spared a jail term.
In January this year, Arenas admitted that he illegally brought his unloaded automatic .44 calibre pistol to a team party at his home. He was fined $50,000 last year for negligently storing a firearm unsecured in a closet and for failing to report his firearm to Washington police on time. “I have learned a very serious lesson about life… This whole experience has helped me mature,” Arenas said to the judge in the court today.
Arenas still has to finish his undergraduate education at the University of Arizona to fulfil an agreement with team officials before he completes the final payment of his five-year, $111 million contract. Arenas should not be sentenced to any jail time, according to his lawyer. He pleaded guilty last month to misdemeanor negligent storage of a gun and failing to register a firearm.

What gives? According to data collated by Citigroup Research, net inflows into Asian funds have been relatively low at $2.1 billion (Rs9,828 crore today) since August. In the same period, net inflows into emerging bond funds were $8 billion (Rs32,920 crore today), while into developed bond funds they were $1.4 billion (Rs5,030 crore). Together, that is around $9.6 billion (Rs37,950 crore) versus expected inflows of $13 billion to $14 billion. This has been attributed to a clampdown on flows in China and increased openness in better-performing funds in other regions. The celebration of the Nativity of Jesus properly belongs to the Faith and worship of the Christian Church….
Before the middle of the fifth century, the Faith and worship of the Christian Church did not include the celebration of the Birth of Jesus. Looking for calm? Head to Rüschlikon in Zurich, where, eight metres below the Binnig and Rohrer Nanotechnology Centre, IBM Research has six new "noise-free" labs. "The noise floor is never more than -30 dBU, making it possible to obtain using electronically-shielded rooms what previously was only achievable through expensive acoustic methods," explains Thomas Watson, the overall lab manager. In other words, they are going really, really quiet indeed.
And don't worry, Watson will help out with all those annoying measurements. By using special sensors at one-metre interval from floor to ceiling on left, the acoustic variance is recorded in real time for assessing any leaks. Only with this level of quiet, have IBM successfully extracted both chemical sensors that detect gases the body releases when we're sick, as well as tiny equipment they are using to measure the smallest imbalances in the body — one thousand times smaller than the width of your hair, according to the Canadian Medical Association Journal.

Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations is being done on the basis of ever-increasing levels of detail. Of course, there are many situations in which this is entirely appropriate, including problem-solving and project implementation.
IT can, however, also play a vital role in strategic decision-making. In particular, designed to support decision making, there is a far wider potential for information technology than in the past. This means that we have to look at information in a new way. In this, too, technology is a key element. It is also becoming possible to compile data on issues which go well beyond conventional management reporting. Ever more detailed computer comparison are being achieved. But more importantly, the "near-thinking" required by this type of computerized processing is itself becoming more and more important in strategic decision-making.

According to a report issued by the Pew Research Center, American adults have a sub-par knowledge of basic science. The organization surveyed 3,278 Americans of various social, racial and academic backgrounds. The questionnaire targeted US citizens aged 18 and older and asked 12 science-related questions — ten of which were found commonly on high school examinations. In line with previous data, tasks relating to solar impact, physics, Earth science, and DNA all proved difficult for most test-takers. Only 32 percent of Goodwin College’s 2014 graduating class failed to fill in more than 10 of 12 science spaces on the Pew test.
Community college graduates distinguished themselves above all other categories despite the poorer scores, proof that additional academic education is not necessarily the solution for science knowledge. Though the report concluded that the general US population fares poorly when it comes to science literacy, programs like the one at Goodwin are changing the landscape. For incoming freshman students, Goodwin’s Science Academy provides a boot camp experience where upon matriculation student science courses are challenging and exciting

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had stopped in Sacramento, California, before it was rerouted to Seattle so the worker could safely exit the plane's rear cargo door.
The airline initially said the Boeing 737 had been cleared to land shortly after 2 p.m. It was rerouted to Paine Field, just south of the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, "after the cargo loader became unresponsive," according to a flight log read by The Associated Press.
The passenger's flight was cancelled, according to a state Department of Transportation spokesman. The pilot announced the change of plans, apologizing to the passengers, the AP said.
According to a Department of Transportation statement, the worker had crawled inside the cargo area and fallen asleep.
The worker was airlifted to a local hospital, Alaska Airlines said in a statement. His condition was not known

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of scam tactics during tax season each of the past four years.
* Bogus e-mails that appear to come from tax software providers requesting financial institutions to update taxpayer information are a recurrent threat.
Fraudsters may also send an electronically-forged bank letter purportedly on official letterhead that contains attachments to give the appearance of credibility. In this scenario, the finance employees are directed to transfer all funds from a bank account to another account under the taxpayer's control, and may request that the account origination fees and additional taxes be paid in a certain way.
Then, the fraudster requests that the employee forward all the new account paperwork to the e-mail address provided on the tax software website form in order for the taxpayer to complete the transaction.
The IRS says the employee must independently verify that the e-mail has come from the tax software's

The Office of Multicultural Affairs facilitates the Navigation mentoring program that pairs students with a faculty or staff member who will serve as their Navigation Partner throughout their journey at the University of Dayton. A Navigation Partner can answer questions about course planning and graduation eligibility and help with registration, understanding the campus environment and students’ academic careers. Students have opportunities to learn about campus student support groups and student clubs and share tips about staying on top of course work; find out about campus resources and where to go for help in a crisis. Partners meet on campus one-on-one or over Skype (or similar video-messaging service). A Navigation Partner can help students craft an email message to send to the partner’s office, explain courses and faculty responsibilities and share the student perspective on campus experiences. Students choose their Navigation Partner by participating in the mentoring program’s pre-adjustment orientation each summer.
Contact: Anahit Kesernakoun for details and referrals.

Howard Dean formally announced on January 11 that he was officially entering the race for chair of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) which will be voted on in early February. The ex-governor of Vermont had been unofficially running for chairman since last fall, after the disastrous results of the the election in November. The official announcement comes two weeks before the Feb. 11 primary.

There is no easy option for Northern Ireland after Brexit.
Deciding on post-Brexit border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is becoming an issue for which the phrase "the devil is in the detail" could have been invented.
On a number of occasions US President Donald Trump has expressed strong opposition to anything that might potentially reduce economic relations between the United States and the European Union, including the open borders that exist between Ireland and Northern Ireland.
And while it is possible, perhaps inevitable, that the leadership of the UK, Ireland, and the EU will be determined to go all-out in pursuing an agreement with President Trump, it will by no means be straightforward to construct a border - either with high barriers, technology-enabled microsensor fences or controlled crossings - which is acceptable to both Dublin and London, as newer border arrangements now cannot be seen as subordinating Northern Ireland to the EU after Brexit.

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that analysis, given the publicized struggles of other high-profile giants of the digital world in its attempts to carve out a large digital pie in China. But there is a very different cause underlying the failure of China’s “digital giants,” particularly the once lauded Chinese e-commerce powerhouse Alibaba (BABA.US), and I believe it’s no picnic in China to sell out to a competitor, regardless of your position. Investors should probably welcome Uber’s result so far.
Japanese investor Masayoshi Son bought into Alibaba in 2008 through Yahoo (YHOO.US), following the lead of his Chinese partner, China Mobile (CHL.US), and the American firm Yahoo itself. James Vincent Napoli, 41, of Eltingville and Boca Raton died April 7, 2019, at home in bed of a heart attack.

The rapid expansion of the digital market since the mass move to electronic trading has exacerbated already heightened concerns from buyers and authors that digital ads be honoured to the same standards as analogue out-of-home (OOH) sales.

[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the removal of both the Queen Elizabeth II and John F Kennedy Jr terminals in favor of new ones. The final proposal will include a railway link to New York's core.
JFK is the top world cargo airport. It is known for having highly airplane-intensive operations with dozens of planes taking off and taking off again, only a few dozen meters from each other.
The airport welcomes about 64 million travelers annually and employs about 12,000 employees.

It may be cheaper than driving, but commuting by public transport can still be pretty pricey.
Commuting to work via public transportation is usually cheaper than driving everywhere.
But in these major cities, a monthly pass is pricier than a yearly registration for the same type of car.
Based on the number of registered vehicles per 1,000 people in each city and the estimated price of a monthly pass, it’s possible to get an average amount you would pay to use public transportation.
For instance, in New York it would cost you $1,476 per year for public transportation.
At this rate, it is more cost effective to drive as long as you have a sticker price lower than that.

Most people who support the Bush administration’s generous reinterpretation of the rights of government in the name of fighting terrorism (and many do) do so with the fundamental assumption that they would never be the ones whose civil liberties are most dramatically affected by this reinterpretation. When the rules change, when constraints and qualifiers are dropped, the furthest things from those exercising powers are the people who are directly exposed to their misuse. First it was nonexistent or “incidental” collection of American communications under the Telecommunications Act—until NSA officials proved otherwise. Now it is a handful of lawyers and military strategists at the White House involved in crafting a list of enemy combatants—all known foreign nationals, stateless, enemy belligerents—who may be directly targeted in an effort to capture or kill them. Those first to fall prey to this effort may not be rich corporate executives but homeless men and traumatic-stress-impaired veterans with barely enough mental fortitude to keep their sanity. Federal budget shows big support for Boys & Girls Clubs in Memphis and across the country, which are helping more at-risk youth stay out of trouble and in school.
For more than 56 years, the Boys & Girls Clubs of America have been an invaluable support to at-risk youth in our nation’s inner-cities. Their important work receives a boost in Tuesday’s federal budget, with $43.8 million earmarked for such crucial efforts that help children stay in school and out of trouble.
Those efforts also include a focus on uniformed youth, including veterans and their family members. Boys & Girls Clubs are often the only ones to offer these support services to kids who might otherwise end up in trouble, perhaps abusing illegal substances, running away from home, abusing others, or becoming involved with gangs.

A small VoIP company has had to change its name after being threatened with legal action over its use of the word ‘cloud’ in its name by European Wi-Fi network The Cloud.
Facing a High Court case, Cloudnet Telecommunications chose in late December 2014 to change its name and dropped the word entirely from its URL to www.voipnow.com.
The cloud adaptor recently told Unified Communications it had followed the £3,500 a day step-by-step instructions required to not include the word cloud in its brand.
Victory for The Cloud is restrictive to SMBs, says vendor
The Cloud, meanwhile, has argued its claim is not a substantial one because its brand is a household name. So even if an SMB name was stopped from offering cloud services, it wouldn’t be applicable.
TechWorld has reached out for The Cloud’s perspective and is working to provide more in-depth details.
High Court action
The Cloud case dates back to March 2014 when it blocked Cloudnet Telecommunications’ domain name being registered, and later prompted the firm to change his name.

Surgeon Michael Chopin, Beyond By Chopin Ophthalmology, had a patient who asked what she could do to help prevent his cataracts. “She told me she was on a keto diet because she was going through menopause and someone told her it would reduce the risk of breast cancer,” Chopin says. "After researching a bit, the next time she came in for an exam, she came back excited to say she had begun to notice other benefits. Her body fat had dropped by 30 percent and her weight had been reduced by 10 pounds," Chopin says. "She started feeling better, looking better. YOUNGSTOWN — Police said a man listed as homeless arrested Monday afternoon was in possession of $1,120 not his own.
Troy H. Cruise, 40, homeless, told officers he was walking down the street when a man who lives at 1413 Wycco Ave. gave him the money, according to a report.
Despite Cruise’s story, an officer who investigated the case said he saw ulcer scars on Cruise that he said matched wound patterns for injuries he might have sustained during a beating in May in front of an apartment.
Officers said Cruise was arrested for petty theft, one count of receiving stolen property, one count of falsification, one count of trafficking in drugs and possession of drug paraphernalia.

This year’s video shows a succession of text messages between two friends — one of whom has been working up the nerve to end an abusive relationship. The Indianapolis City-County Council approved Monday night about $7.1 million of property tax abatements for the downtown campus the pharmaceutical company is building.

“Expect nothing but great things from our city and nation’s signature drugmaker for many, many years to come and be part of that success story of economic growth and development here in our region,” Ricks added.
Lilly’s tax abatement agreement specifies the company must occupy the campus before it can get the tax break.

WASHINGTON (AP) - Donald Trump holds the most powerful office in the world. But he's dogged by insecurity over his loss of the popular vote in the election and a persistent frustration that the legitimacy of his presidency has been challenged from many sides - including his own attorney general.
It's a reality that was underscored Friday when Trump fired FBI Director James Comey, prompting comparisons to Watergate.
When Trump entered the White House seven months ago, some advisers expected he would get used to wearing the mantle of the U.S. presidency, becoming comfortable in the role. Instead, he appears to have same insecurities he expressed in the gilded complex he occupied for 40 years: a legitimacy question.
Former aides and acquaintances recall Trump - who appealed to rank-and-file voters with unfaltering confidence in himself - fidgeted when confronted with that nagging question throughout his the campaign and leading up to his vote of confidence last November. Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was mapped by lost trails, Native American legends, or Europeans just stepping out into the unknown, hoping to sell the land they were traveling through. But that is all changed now, thanks to Google Maps.
Modern technology has advanced the interaction between science, theory, analysis, and art by allowing experts to interpret quantities of information that would have been useless to them before. Now, the story of the world measured in feet, miles, and shading could be shared by anyone with a computer.
I like these web-based interactive maps because they don’t just tell you where things are; they put you in touch (via a computer screen) with the natural beauty of the spaces themselves. Imagine what it is like to climb Stone Mountain or dive to its base. You can strongly relate what you are seeing to what you have learned, offering up an enriched experience almost guaranteed to bring you back.

The minister said the army restored calm and that routine life and tourism operations were back to normal.

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing most life on the nearby planets, and can serve to disperse the unruly wanderers to other parts of the Milky Way. Though they tend to occur at random in a galaxy, they ultimately serve to enhance the variety and complexity of star-life. Although there may be shining lives out there, the grumpy, sluggish fools that inhabit this planet make one wonder if Earth is meant for such naïve and foolish beings. The solar flares that occasionally erupt on the sun have sections of the surface of the planet bathed in extended radio- and phosphorescent-colored light. There are no night modes or shades of light that we get here, nor is there any kind of moon direction. There are no real colors to speak of, and people do not like chlamides who's eyes are color-blind.

Performance Reviews Are Pointless And Insulting -- So Why Do They Still Exist?
I'm the HR Director for a growing manufacturing firm. I started the job in July. I report to the CEO.
I'm tasked with implementing a set of tools that includes a 360 and an online performance review invitation that occurs mid-January. We actually don't require a performance review; we only "suggest" that people do them. If you don't do one, no penalty. But I'd honestly like to help employees improve their careers, and this tool can do that. I also want clear documentation of what I have to work with as a manager.
I understand the tool is necessarily limited -- it needs to be online and to maintain some elements of confidentiality. But all of my managers come back to me and say, "It's a waste of time; the ratings are inaccurate." And they're right. Oscar Preps: Will Rain Spoil the Show?
L.A.'s worst storm in two years is predicted to hit this weekend, but if you think that'll slow the Academy Awards down, you got another thing coming.
Its hard to think of a city where it rains more than Los Angeles is known for its sunshine. I remember being at the Academy Awards recently as the sun shone on the A-Listers and security tow trucks hit the red carpet. And that was years ago, the sun prancing proudly around the pick-the-winners in stiletto heels.
Since then, it hasn't rained at the Oscar Awards on at least three occasions, but I remember the off years as well. It was raining -- big, hard gusts -- at the presentation last year until the moment Halle Berry won her Oscar. Suddenly, the rain stopped, the sun shone and Berry accepted her award; from there, it was all glittery shoe bling.

Tenders to redevelop Union Terrace Gardens will close in the middle of this month, it has been revealed.
Aberdeen City Council has still to appoint a contractor for the multi-million-pound revamp of the quality green space in the city centre.
The garden is tucked behind Marischal Court and positioned over a multi-storey car park.
Construction work is expected to start in spring of next year, with an estimated opening date of May 2018.
The tender papers sent out to developers, architects and others specify that the estate is due to close on October 15.
Aberdeen City Council last month said it was only accepting bids until mid-October as previously planned, allowing two extra days for final submissions.
A spokesperson said: “The process has not been stopped. We’ve not stopped it, no.”
City Garden Project leader Michael Cook said the timetable remained the same.

Al Du Toit has been elected mayor of the town he calls his hometown since 1991 and he aims to open up this dry Northern Cape town to as many people as possible.

Tim Russert discusses his childhood, faith, the catholic church, religion mixing with politics, and a life of service with On Faith's Sally Quinn.
Tim Russert, the NBC commentator who revolutionized political journalism and then shocked us with his sudden passing away Friday, was a devout Catholic as children of his parents' generation often are. His Sunday school teachers read St. Paul's letters to him that Sunday school teachers often read us and to our children, and many of his questions about how we should worship and pray in the church or whether a catholic like him should make a run for the White House were explored and answered.
Then again, as he did with all his big questions, he asked his catholic faith to explain for him why bad things happen (like Camp David Agreements and the murder of a former prime minister), why it's wrong to assume we are greater than other people, and where the catholic church could have an impact in the world.

It's also pretty much the two basic ingredients for what makes that beloved Starbucks drink taste that way, pumpkin purée and nutmeg.

LinkedIn has responded to criticism of its "social ads" feature over its use of members' names and photos in advertisements on its website.
Many LinkedIn members have complained that the use of their details in this way has gone awry. Links to advertising opportunities are to appear in a range of places on the "professional" network, including alongside members' updates on the website and inside their emails.

LinkedIn says if some users don't wish to be part of the ads, they should send their organisational metadata file to ads@linkedin to be opted out.

Mariemont has won a $400,000 matching-funds state grant to build an addition to village hall that will include a Native American Cultural Center.
MARIEMONT – Construction has begun on an addition at Mariemont Village Hall to include a Native American Cultural Center that’s being built with the help of a $400,000 matching-funds state grant. Through tax and bond funding for a parking lot, the operational cost for the Native American Center may be somewhere around $80,000 a year, Mayor Alex Reynolds said Friday, reserving much of the project’s funding for education, the arts and culture.
The plan calls for a facility big enough to display artifacts and history, but small enough to fit into and between existing offices and existing village hall space, Reynolds said. The Native American Center could also be used as an events space, he said. “We are looking to start as soon as possible.” The current village hall was built in 1958 and place in the National Register of Historic Places in March 2006.

These cellars get a new sense of purpose the moment they're opened to the public. It's just measures of a winery determined to continue sharing premium wine experiences with everyone who takes the time to enjoy it.
Outside the restaurant there's a large wooded area with grass and flowers all around. A great spot to unwind and relax.

UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers said they calculated that a single sheet of the device distributed over urban rooftops could supply enough electricity to replace about a dozen to 15% of the energy used in these cities by residential and commercial electricity customers, as well as generate power for electric vehicles.
The team, based both in Iran and at UCLA, said the device could make a significant difference in Iran's power supply, as well as more than potential in countries like the United States and China in three to five years.
The new device is a device panels made of plastic substances called biopolymers. It extracts electricity from cold temperatures of falling snow by melting the snow inside a mesh, releasing water, and simultaneously activating surface droplets of salty water to generate an electric current through a micro-grid. He then forms salt water droplets that provide electricity to tiny bacteria that grow on the material.

“The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of Muir – poet, philosopher, and activist of the wild – as a jumping off point.
Opening with moving footage of an artist’s rendering of Muir’s birthplace – a small cottage where a family nurtured the young boy’s sensibilities – “The Unruly Mystic” illustrates his early curiosity about his surroundings. Shielded from the lesson-oriented dogmatic teachings of the church and religious dogma, Muir instead found deep connections between his personal jungle-gym, the young genius himself, and later landscapes across the United States and eventual other parts of the world. Invariably moving to jungle scenes that connect and complement Muir’s stirring writings are visual ruminations on paintings and art that inspired and motivated Muir’s own explorations and prose.

So you're renting a car? It's no big deal, unless something goes wrong. Here's a checklist based on our own experiences and on the rental cars we've seen in our shop lately.
Get Insurance before You Land
If you or anyone in your party has a problem with driving, see if your home or auto policy will pay for liability if there's an accident That only works if your agent has been told about your trip, unless there's an auto rental exclusion to the policy. You'd be guinea pig if you had a wreck and the insurance company denied coverage. Check with your agent and find out, because this limitation can be a counter-intuitive surprise. In either case, reconsider signing your name until you've checked. In our lean years, we've gone without rental car insurance to avoid outrageously expensive insurance from the rental companies. On the other hand, see if your homeowner's policy provides supplementary liability with the rental car, and you can drive with less stress.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – tracing different geometric patterns into the light transmuting blue surface. My mother noticed a fragment of the modernist pattern I had created and printed it in black on a tablecloth.
Decades later, when shopping in Edinburgh one day, I stopped in a George Street bookstore where I was introduced to the iconic classic Bauhaus 2 software, by Werner Jekelius and Martin Kluger. This was around 2001 & I was 25 and fell in love with the software, luckily this was before CAD became digital. I can still remember seeing the Bauhaus front door, Bionic Garden logo and Babette pop up as we looked at the sample images.
I started university the following year at Glasgow School of Art and started to incorporate simple form with colour to my designs – the element of Bauhaus resonated.

I have had the luxury of meeting over 500 startups at Red Rocket Ventures over the last three years. And, typically, once they get over the awkwardness that attendants are “interns” under the guise of an MBA program, they talk to me about what they are doing, what they need and, most importantly, what to call the software they are building.
As a reminder, an MVP—or minimum viable product—is not just a slimmed down version of your software. It’s a visual depiction of the core elements a customer will encounter. It’s something that people will pay for… and a means to obtain feedback from future customers.
On my side of the table—the right side where a closed door may lead to a captive audience—I tell startup founders what to name their products. "The core element that attracts users to spend money? Google is drawing the curtains on 32-bit only apps from 1 August 2019, as new applications or updates to existing applications that do not support 64-bit processors will not be allowed on the Google Play Store from that date. The policy applies to smartphones, which will stop installing 32-bit only apps soon but will take three years or more for tablets and other devices to go 64-bit only.
Even though this move is hardly a surprise, as 32-bit architecture, which adds security and efficiency features to 64-bit applications, has been around for years and popular A-grade phones up to recently launched phones support APIs such as Snapdragon 636, Snapdragon 660, Snapdragon 845, and Nougat which support 64-bit systems, the transition is happening faster than expected due to the world turning digital at scale.

Regulators often struggle to keep up with the rapid pace of new technologies which hurts businesses and consumers.
Whether it’s a cutting-edge gadget, an exciting software platform, or an advanced app store, logistics, telecommunications and financial operators all need effective ways to launch their new products.
To avoid the need for regulators to repeatedly authorise businesses as new products become available, the best method may be to turn to a similar approach used by carmakers: authorising certification procedures that are oriented to guaranteeing safety and quality.
Berk Maramerial, Member of the steering committee of the EU Blockchain Observatory & Forum answer to a question on Automotive Certification and Blockchain.
Making such regulation channelled through a central authority is all well and good with regard to safety as a car or its parts would break rather quickly. However, it’s difficult to imagine or monitor whether a secure blockchain-based protocol is acting correctly, as it runs 24 hours a day. As a general rule, this means that platforms built using software require a greater level of trust on the part of the regulator.

Life expectancy for kidney transplant recipients is normally 35 years whereas, in the last 20 years, Harry has put in twice that time.

As social media continues to grow in importance as an outpost for traditional media content, – as — so do the metrics that companies are using to measure its impact. Although Facebook posts have traditionally ruled, a distinction is starting to occur because neither Twitter nor Instagram provide a like button about the millions of tweets and photos published every week. The volume of Facebook posts, with their like button and millions of dollars in shenanigans, has obscured measures of engagement.
In the past, Engagement was defined as a combination of likes, re-shares, and post-shares to arrive at an aggregated measure of engagement per post. However, this definition of engagement assumes that social users respond with each and every post. Well actually pretty much the opposite is true. ASTONISHING photographs captured the Perseid meteor shower which lit up night skies around the world last night.
The annual event is caused by the Earth crossing the debris from the tail of the Swift-Tuttle comet.
One photo shows the Orion, Taurus and Aries constellations in the Greek city of Trikala.
The AEGEAN sky was lit up by a shooting star
Another shows the trail of about 30 meteors streaking away from a lakeside spot in Michigan.
Another photo shows the Perseids’ glowing light streaking through the sky of Trikala, Greece.
More than 100 images of the Perseid meteor shower made the cut this year.
Before that, the Perseids lit up the clouds and cloud forests above the Arctic Circle in Finnish Lapland.
The constellation Perseus has been given its name after Perseus, the mythological Greek hero who battled Medusa’s head

In the San Antonio Independent School District, the focus is on breaking down - school size that is, as the Texas city seeks to turn its eight large public high schools (average enrollment: 2,000) into seven medium-sized schools (average enrollment: 1,200) characterized by smaller schools in larger buildings. Should the seven smaller schools perform well when compared with the eight large schools they replace, the district then can make the transition to even smaller schools. And because SAISD is not overly enamored of small schools, it doesn't plan to do what other districts have done to accommodate them - educate fewer students per school. To accommodate smaller school administrations, the district is creating what is called a regional high school. In that model, schools grouped with three to five other high schools from different parts of the city. "These aren't really small, separate high schools," says Jacinto Garza, SAISD chief communications officer. This year marks the 150th anniversary of the end of the Civil War and the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln. To mark the occasion, PBS is airing a remastered edition of Ken Burns' landmark 2001 documentary "The Civil War" on pemium cable channel PBS and free PBS video streaming for 150 hours and 50 minutes from March 4-20.
The HD remaster of the series was funded by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and The Ogden Fund. The series was also remastered in 1997, 2001 and 2005. Five million people tuned in when "The Civil War" premiered, and Burns received the National Humanities Medal for work on the series from President Bill Clinton in 2002. In all, the series collected more than 40 awards and honors.
The series is a meditation on the cost of war - and a moving account of the slumbering fires of freedom and equality in the heart of a young democracy.

The Severn Crossing tolls will be abolished in December. From December 13 all vehicles using the bridges will be able to travel for free.
The change marks Prince Charles being bestowed with the title 60th Earl of Tamar, meaning he owns the toll bridges.
He will still be able to collect the five-pence (7.3p) toll toll and is likely to continue to fund its meteorological and tidal monitoring facilities, as these will be essential for dredging the channel in a future super-highway for amphibious armoured vehicles.
A royal spokesman said: “The change in ownership will make no difference to the running of the bridge at present. It is a matter for Field Roads Bridge Ltd when they next come to a renewal of the Act under which they run the bridge. It is understood the Act comes up for renewal in 2015.”
Road tolls have already been abolished on the four A roads that run from the bridge into Wales.

Remnants of bloody rule echo throughout Indonesian archipelago.
As Indonesia marks the death of its former president, survivors of Soeharto's military backed government - from East Timor to Aceh - remember decades of bloodshed generation after generation.
In the southern city of Bengkulu, across the Strait of Malacca from Singapore, the story is well-known. In 1974, when Indonesia occupies the once Portuguese colony, Nurhayati Hamdan's brother was kidnapped and, by way of an inquisitorial interview in another country, held on the bareness of a soccer pitch.
"The person kicked him with his foot from far away," she recalls. "The attack lasted for five hours straight. It was so terrible to hear my mother's cry. She was calling my mother's name and telling my mother not to worry. My mother instantly questioned me about my brother's whereabouts, and that was the first time I saw my mother cry, telling me that they were after family members who advocated independence."

KPH Dream Cricket,the owner of IPL franchisee Kings XI Punjab and the publisher of Cricket Age,has narrowed down its losses sharply by a hefty 95%.The Kolkata-based company,which spent Rs 54 crore for Kings XI in the first year of the Indian Premier League (IPL-4),says if its revenues go up,it is capable of clocking an operating margin of 11% in Year 2 (of the fourth edition of the IPL).Statutory laws require listed companies to retain 20% of the net profit in blocked amounts against the current maximum undistributed profit term loan (UDTL).KPH intends to keep anything over the mandatory 20%-Retained Reserve Fund intact before transferring the undistributed profit to the shareholders.At present,the company has a retained equity to the tune of Rs.153.76-crore.

LAHORE: The provincial capital, Lahore is among the most polluted cities in the world and urgent action needs to be taken to tackle this issue. Air pollution caused by traffic, industries, crop burning and burning rubbish piles can severely aggravate respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, putting residents at higher risk of death, including the young and the old. When it comes to environmental pollution, Lahore is not alone – a report released on Friday by Greenpeace said a list of European polluters included two automobile manufacturers along with companies like Samsung Electronics and British Petroleum. The incriminating data covered thousands of the world’s top firms, each analysed on their climate plans and the progress they had made in tackling pollution problems – telling the world’s top polluters and the world what currently stands in the way of big industry committing to proactive preventative action on climate and environmental problems. The report also shines a light on the corporations that are blatantly and happily polluting in the name of providing affordable, high quality goods to people.

Some, but not all, technology employees at the Agriculture Department's Forest Service have dodged a bullet. They received final notice that management had chosen their reorganization plan over a commercial outsourcing proposal submitted under an Office of Management and Budget Expedited processing initiative.
Peg Arable, the Forest Service's contracting officer for shared services, sent agency employees a letter with good news on Thursday. "I am pleased to report that our Education, Training and Technical Assistance reorganization plan was chosen and is in the process of being executed as scheduled in FY 2005," she wrote. "The plan presents the option to outsource services only once to commercial firms, and this process concludes today."
Arable also cautioned Forest Service employees that there would probably still be positions eliminated. More than 97 percent of scientists agree that humans are worsening global warming by pumping billions of tons of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. LUSAKA (Reuters) - Kansai Plascon, owned by Tokyo-listed Kansai Paint Co Ltd, has launched the world’s first mosquito repellant paint in Zambia as authorities grapple with outbreaks of the dengue fever.
The inaugural roll-out of the paint began on Wednesday in Lusaka in line with the country’s Global Health Security Agenda effort to improve outbreak preparedness in health services and ultimately work towards “the elimination of the threat of infectious diseases”.
Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne disease and some houses in Lusaka have become infested with visitors who also end up infecting local residents.
National Health Commission national coordinator for global health funding, Ruth Mwale, said there would be an awareness campaign around the country for people to embrace repellent paint, a product she said was not currently available in Zambia or Africa.
She said about 3,500 primary and secondary schools have been hit by infectious diseases.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - The global price of cashew nuts has jumped nearly 10 percent over the past week, after Tanzania’s government started buying the entire country’s stock at a premium after sporadic unrest in the northern city of Arusha.
But apart from a harvest season weighing on availability, prices for the tropical nut are being pressured by the value of the Indian rupee falling to a record low against major currencies this year.
“When the (Tanzanian) government started their stock buying program, that caused prices in the open market to move up,” said Gemie Maranda from Kaloleni Cashews, division head at wholesaler CTIS Group. “We’re seeing levels of 60 percent above where they were a week ago.

The Marine Corps’ footprint in Afghanistan is changing dramatically as a drawdown in forces continues throughout the summer.
The latest changes include a shift in central Helmand province in which one infantry battalion — 3rd Battalion, 6th Marines — left the Marjah District on Friday.
On Saturday morning, the Marines handed off security to the Afghan National Army’s 215th Corps.
The battalion’s High Mobility Artillery Rocket System, or HIMARS, fired off the final round of the 28-day Operation Park in the city of Marjah and the district’s “lonely willow” farm.
Since the launch of Operation Helmand Viper in February, the Marines have fired off 60 weapons of mass destruction against insurgents, the biggest being the 240mm M142 HIMARS.
Marines left behind will move to Ramadi, Iraq, to take part in Operation Enduring Freedom Atlantic in 2012, utilizing Afghanistan’s skills in village stabilization measures.

Prepare for major changes in personal data sharing. The new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a comprehensive plan to protect the privacy and confidentiality of EU citizens’ data, officially goes into effect May 25. It could also impact the legal landscape of the United States.
In the United States, both public and private-sector organizations – including small to medium-sized businesses – are under increasing pressure to strengthen data protection, as cybercriminals are getting craftier by increasing their attacks.

The president had a solid showing among his key ’08 demographic constituencies.
A solid showing among his key ’08 demographic constituencies —coupled with a small dose of economic optimism — and a feeling that he is now president gave Barack Obama a 6-point boost since the CBS News poll of three weeks ago. That May survey, taken immediately after his Cairo speech, found Obama to be stuck in the low 40s.
But the recovery speech Tuesday appears to have helped. Among independents who listened to or saw the speech, six in ten say they were “enthusiastic” in their view of Obama’s leadership (see first chart), compared to four in ten independents who say the same of his November leadership speech. Fifty-five percent of Democratic reactions are positive as compared to 46% for Republicans.
The speech had the effect of boosting the president’s performance on various budget and tax items — the economy as a whole and healthcare in particular — and improving Obama’s performance to the point where now more than six in ten Americans approve of his performance as president.

The Navy plans to install a laser weapon prototype on a ship this summer for at-sea testing in the Persian Gulf.
The technology, called the Laser Weapon System, will be the first of its kind to be used in an operational setting, said Rear Adm. Ron Boxall, Navy systems commander of naval integration.
Once installed, the past few months of at-sea testing will be followed by 11 months of at-sea testing. This phase will take place in the Pacific Ocean in order to test the suit systems and long-range effects of the weapon.
Boxall told USNI News on Thursday that 2014 was the first year for LWS, and the next phase of testing is slated for later this year.
Both the Navy and Marine Corps are looking at using this system on a large number of vessels. Boxall said it can fit on most types of vessels, but it is especially designed for sea-based minesweepers and minesweepers that are replacing Destroyers and Frigates to perform mine countermeasure.

Law enforcement is responsible for catching the crooks behind online crime, but it's the private sector that comes to businesses' aid when police are burdened by jurisdiction.
Private companies have become the first aiders of the increasing number of companies falling victim to Internet crime. A host of players including VeriSign, Comodo, Microsoft, Trustwave, McAfee and Symantec are actively working with law enforcement authorities to help trace hackers, delete trojans and issue take-down requests to webmasters who've inadvertently hosted them.
The private security firms that specialize in online protection and the large vendors in anti-virus, online banking and email security offer finders and remedies to corporate India in times of cybercrime. Their responsibility functions much like that of the Red Cross, with the only difference that they more aptly represent specific parts of the human body.

According to a study published today in the New England Journal of Medicine, Femara is a better treatment for early stages of breast cancer than tamoxifen. This doesn’t mean that tamoxifen is bad; in many cases it is a good treatment. But after years and years of stagnation, it doesn’t make sense not to have other options for our breast Cancer patients.Congratulations, Tam!!!!!
Femara is a food and drug administration approved aromatase inhibitor, similar to Arimidex, which is a synthetic steroid derivative. What sets Femara apart from Arimidex is that it is designed to have less toxicity and thus less side effects than Arimidex. This makes it a great option for what is called an adjuvant therapy, wherein one is using an anti-estrogen drug after treatment is complete. Why is this great? Well, because it sure beats radiation to the brain as the side effect of stopping self-grown ovarian estrogen….

JERUSALEM (AFP) - A Palestinian tried to stab a private security guard at an Israeli checkpoint in the West Bank on Saturday (Oct 24) and was shot dead, in the latest in a string of such attacks in recent weeks.
The would-be attacker's name and the name of the security company at the checkpoint were not released. A police official said the entrance and exit of the checkpoint were blocked during police and border agents investigation.
Jiha, an AFP correspondent at the scene, observed that the young attacker wore a backpack and that platelets of blood could be seen on the ground about 30 metres from the scene.
Medics arrived at the scene and carried off the body on a stretcher, presumably to take him away to be autopsied and photographed.
Deadly knife attacks by Palestinians targeting Israeli soldiers and settlers have risen in the past several months in the West Bank and east Jerusalem, and security forces at suspected spots respond by shooting dead the assailants.
On Wednesday, a Palestinian was killed in east Jerusalem

The capital of France’s Loire region is more than just a provincial tourist destination. An hour’s drive from Brittany, Nantes is a lively city that has grown from medieval roots into a buzzing place to enjoy France’s third natural wine region (after Bordeaux and Burgundy). The Loire also exports fine foods including sturdiest duck, chiles-braised and cured, its best carried by half-peck baskets worn across the shoulders; and chives, whose trimmings from great tartines made a nice addition to a salad. The produce quality here reflects the climate of Loire and Ré, an Atlantic coast that is rock-coral shallow, best for swimming lakes.

COLLEGE PARK, Md. (AP) - Northwestern and Maryland have followed similar paths to this point in the football season.
Where they go from here could well be determined by the result of their first-ever meeting.
The Wildcats (6-1) claimed an outright, undefeated title in their first season in the Big Ten, all while racking up school records. Their accomplishments were a bit overshadowed, at least in the immediate future, by the viability of a potential $3 billion plan to expand the league with Notre Dame and tentatively bring in Rutgers and Maryland.
``They did a phenomenal job. Now it's on the conference to look at each of us and see what fans want, what can be done,'' said Wildcats coach Pat Fitzgerald, who is an avid advocate of the expansion.
Whatever the fate of the future Big Ten, the Wildcats can still claim to be one of the the most eye-catching storylines from this season so far.

Ten months on and despite six arrests, no one has been charged or brought to justice for the murder of Wolverhampton teenager Keelan Wilson.
The family of the 15-year-old have spoken out about how they are fed up with the slow pace of the investigation and are coming to terms with a tragedy that’ll never be healed.
Surjit Khan QC, head of the firm’s serious crimes department, has been representing the Wilson family since day one and acts for Keelan’s father and has been supporting the family throughout.
Surjit is now appealing to one of the six men to finally break the code of silence. As daytime shows continue to endlessly pay lip service to honouring youngsters, who warrant being heard, the family of the victim have just two requests for anyone who knows or heard anything – to work with the law to give justice, not anecdote justice; and to consider their pain, please think of Keelan and do what is human.
Two of the four drivers caught in dashcams speeding have been convicted already, but the investigation is ongoing.

CAIRO, IL (KFVS) - Illinois American Water-Cairo District is in the process of returning to its normal water source this week.
Construction has been completed at the Cairo Water Treatment Plant to improve the quality of the water treatment process. Once the mustard layer is removed from the treatment flocculation basin, the Cairo Water Treatment Plant will return to operation.
Crews are currently reacquainting areas served by our ground water sources to drinking water supplies, starting with reverse osmosis method, then ending with hydrogen peroxide, says Illinois American Water in a release.
Customers can expect their water to turn cloudy at first, however, over the next few hours, the cloudy water will clear and the water will return to drinking water quality by mid-week.
To avoid water quality issues, Illinois American customers asked to preserve the water used for the treatment as well as the operational water for the water treatment conducted until the final stages of treatment which includes use of hydrogen peroxide.

August. The name alone conjures up visions of sunny beaches, barbecues, and quiet time.
“I see August as a great opportunity to ask what is going to come in the fall, get preliminary information in time for harvest, and manage any fall pest and weed issues,” says Iowa State University Extension horticulturist Christopher Enstrom.
August is perfect for securing supplies and tools, as well as gathering and maintaining the needed green muscle for fall – your lawn and plantings. What’s right for your yard now is not what will work for it in the fall, Enstrom says, so start putting that yard now to ready for its needs later.
The author walks his plants to monitor for pests and diseases that may develop.
For trees and shrubs, shape your plant for the winter and look for iron and shade deficiencies. Says Enstrom, “Many trees are losing their leaves now, a good time to look them over and cut off some small limbs if needed.”

Notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne is being investigated for a Facebook comment poking fun at last week's terror attacks.
French prosecutors said Monday they were investigating notorious anti-Semitic comic Dieudonne for a Facebook comment mocking last week's terror attacks.
One day after the attacks that killed 129, Dieudonne wrote on his Facebook page: "I feel like Charlie Coulibaly," the name given to the terrorist who killed four people in a kosher supermarket during the attacks.
"Charlie Coulibaly shooting at the army is an attack that corresponds to my deepest convictions. Adios democracy. Long live freedom of expression, such as I practice wherever I like."
Dieudonne has been found guilty of inciting racial hatred so often that France's highest court, the Court of Cassation, ordered a suspended jail sentence and a €20,000 fine.
He has called for "death to the Jews."
